reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fraud and Lies
OK I know that the mods are keeping a tight leash on the forums here and they are shutting down everything that is pointing out the truth so I am going lash out and hope that a few people see this before it gets locked or myself banned like many others have before.

There are a lot of Early Access games on steam. Most of them have a capable and dedicated development team behind them. We all know this, we are all playing their games. We know what to expect from Alphas, Betas, Early Access etc etc. And this isn't it. This game has changed very very little for more than a year now. And they are still taking peoples money for it.

The people that originally backed this game are for the most part gone - they check in every few months hoping that something has changed but it hasn't. At this stage the only people that are happy with this game are those that have recently bought it in the last couple of months and don't know that a patch isn't 'just around the corner', and those that are friends with the devs who jump on every negative review and defend it with the usual Alpha"
recommended:
or "refactoring" excuses.

We aren't stupid. We have played plenty of Early Access games before. They all need to be refactored a couple of times during their development as the scope of the interest in the game increases. All the early access games we are playing are doing the same. Castle Story is NOT unique in this.

The devs just use refactoring as an excuse for having not produced anything notable for more than a year. This is rubbish. They have accumulated near enough to a million dollars to work on this project and all they do is stall.

I know there are a lot of others out there that are just as fed up with this rubbish
hoursPlayed: and I hope it serves as a lesson to everyone to be very careful as to what they back with Early Access games. There a plenty of good ones out the with dedicated developers
voteText: but there are also a few rotten eggs.\n\nI'd like to hear from everyone that has been through the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥e and all those that were banned for speaking out about this
helpfulPercent: but I know they probably have given up on this game plus anyway it won't be long before this thread is locked down and removed anyway. I feel sorry for everyone that wasted their money - I had hoped for something special too."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was an original backer of this game since it has been on Kickstarter, and If you think 28 hours is long, you haven't seen how many hours I put into it before it was on steam. This game is nothing that was shown of the trailer, and hasn't even begun to show it either.

I loved playing this when it was first in the prototype and to be honest it has only improved since, but that isn't saying much at all. I have lost COUNTLESS hours of this game to my bricktrons not working properly and it just keeps happening, the won't move, won't work, etc. Multiplayer is just out of the question because it's broken to all hell, so don't even bother going through the trouble. Not the mention the game was in prototype for OVER A YEAR. that's bad, Don't even bother with the game. The islands are boring and repetitive, it should be randomly generated, not the same old crappy map. It's simply boring, broken, and just flat out annoying.

EDIT:

Congratz, Sauropod Studio, It's been 2 years since you released the game to the public and It's still in Early Access. Really, I accomodate you and your hard work for this terribly optimized, bugged game. It seems improvement has obviously been made. (Obvious Sarcasm)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Update 10FEB16:

Just wanted to update again to keep this review current with development.  Yup, nothing has changed since last time.  Update done.

Ok, there are many patch notes, none of them actual content, all of them coincide with the winter sales event.  Dev's are still trying to grab cash while clumsily and incompetantly releasing trivial updates in time for a sale.  Game has actually regressed, which I didn't think was possible.  UI continues to get worse with every iteration, less intuitive, more complex, less functional, and bugs with AI grow ever more intrusive.  Avoid this game*" at all costs.

* A game is technically any sort of interactive entertainment where choices by a player lead to and change a possible outcome.  None of that happens here
date:
there is no outcome other than you wasting time and money in anticipation of a crash or game breaking bug.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I foolishly paid money for this game when it first came out on steam, in the two years since then they have done nothing of note to the actual game. They've been to PAX east, they've ordered in Castle Story T-shirts and Castle Story plushies, they've hired bearded men to make videos of people looking busy, they've deleted my posts on their youtube videos and they've deleted my posts on the community hub and banned me from posting there again, they've got new gaming rigs, they've painted the walls of their office with a cool Castle Story mural, they've been out in the woods making noises, they've played Magicite, once again what they HAVEN'T done is anything of note to the game itself.

The game in its current state is OK" for a buggy unfinished alpha
date: not much content to speak of
recommended: certainly not worth £14.99. These developers sold everyone a pack of lies and hired people to censor out anyone that calls them out on their unethical
hoursPlayed: thieving and unprofessional behaviour. I can think of many games that have far more content and regular updates and better developers (in terms of listening to and communicating with the community) that cost far less. An example of their lying can be found in the trailer

since then the developers have completely failed to deliver. Any criticism of their unprofessional behaviour by the community is ignored or censored. They have all the money they're going to get so there is simply no more reason to work on the game any further. Instead they are hiring more and more staff to sell it to people on the internet and make promises that will never be kept to create the illusion that they are still working on the game.

I expect that in time they will change the name of the game as War Z did to squeeze out those last few sales before it is consigned to the dustbin of history as yet another kickstarter project that made the devs very rich but utterly failed to deliver on its promises.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DO NOT BUY! Sauropod studios are run by a very small group of inexperienced, unapologetic jerks. If you bought in to this game through kickstarter or early access, they will treat you like crap on the forums.

The only thing Castle Story had going for it was the amazing work the Community Manager: Box, was doing. Box would try to give information to you straight, without breaking any of the company rules, which was very difficult to do. Box would always try to break information down to the community and calm people down who were angry about any of the situations. In the end, the company would give Box misleading information and then blame him for giving out any information to the community.

One of the primary developers for Castle Story is a dev named Thierry. Thierry has a tendency to berate the community for asking questions. On multiple occasions I've read post by him calling out individuals and virtually yelling at them, or the community in general and blaming them for being impatient. The game has been in development for years now, and there has literally been no visual improvement in over a year.

Originally there were weekly updates on what was going on, with an occasional skipping of a week or two. Now there are monthly updates on what is going on. I take that back. There are monthly video blogs about things nobody cares about. These monthly" video blogs have only made it up to the 3rd blog before they seem to have stopped posting them. It has been six weeks since the last video blog

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edit: 01/11/2015
A year after my last update on the game, with the release of 0.5, I tried this once again.

Some new blocks added; beams, supports, stone pillar, curved blocks.

UI - radial menu- is counter intuitive; too slow and complicated. Designed to be used with a gamepad, not keyboard+mouse.

AI is still braindead; pathfinding is as broken as it can be. You still can't build a structure even as small as this without constantly micro maniging.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=546014381
Notice that he is standing right on top the blueprint he should be building. So he can reach it with the block but too dumb to do it.

Started new map, didn't build anything, didn't create any tasks, didn't give any orders, just selected all 5 bricktons and moved them in front of the pre-built castle; 3 of them made it, 2 got stuck on the way. Heh, so much for improved pathfinding.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=546079762

Big Island doesn't even load for me; stuck at Loading %0".

Multiplayer is still as broken as it can be.

Some Halloween stuff again; lanterns and stuff.

And to think they will release this in a few months. I really can't believe Sauropod.

Still no real update

Stay away!

cutting down trees and providing you with building materials on the map you choose; well you have just one map at the moment so no choosing. You issue orders to your minions to gather materials and then you go ahead and lay down blueprints for your minions and they build them.

In Survival mode; you have baddies on top of normal sandbox mode. But they have no AI so they just rush at you. Get an archer or two at a high place and you win. Many times you will have to start a map over and over again to get minions to spawn at all; you will just start with no minions.

There is a catapult in the game with which you can hurl barrels filled with stones or explosive stones to baddies. Very clunky to use; you will end up not using it at all. You don't want to use explosive barrels too; you will just destroy your buildings with it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game about 18 months ago.
It was a great concept, and a really fun game to play with knowing that much more content was promised and on the way.
I was dissapointed to find out shortly after obtaining the game that they were essentially suspending any new features pending a 'refactoring' in the Unity game engine.  The good news was that once this was done, they were to start pumping out feature and content updates much more quickly, since they were including an improved asset pipeline.
That took much more time than their community liason had let on.  The community (other investors in the game) were getting pretty restless.
Finally that refactoring was completed.  A patch was released!  Unfortunately, it had little to no impact on the gameplay.  There were some minor stability improvements but no real new features or content.  We were okay with that because of the promise of much more coming more quickly...
We were then informed that we were being too impatient, and that no new features or content could be done until they finished working on their internal tools (factories).
We were then informed that there would continue to be a suspension of any new features or content while they rewrite the AI engine and the Pathfinding.   No new content could be provided since Why would we give you new content if the AI cant figure out what to do with that content"...
Of course most users abandoned hope that this would ever be completed.   It had been month after month after month of broken promises.   They eventually ended their relationship with the community liason

reviewText:
Early Access Review

They haven't added a single substantial thing to the game since it was originally released in alpha.  Every post on the dev blog is either a behind the scenes change that adds nothing for the player, a minor gui update, or another random person they hired to help with doing those things.  This game has negatively impacted my opinion of both Early Access and Kickstarter as a whole.  Would not reccomend.

0.3.x UPDATE:
Castle Story has recieved a-  well hold on a damn minute, what even has it recieved?  Bigger islands, okay, that's good.  New AI is good as we-  Oh, no the new AI is only on one map/gametype and isn't even near done, not to mention a buggy mess.  All six textures have been updated, but whether or not it's for the better is a point of argument.  The music/sound engine has been redone, but I can't listen a bricktron into getting unstuck from a doorway, so that doesn't affect much.
Guess I'll check back next year after they've redone everything a fourth time and hired three more people.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

├Honest Review┤Review is based on current state of game.

Game Pros
• Base Building
• Resource Gathering
• Day/night Cycle

Game Cons
• AI Path finding is horrible

• Basic map
• Controls are confusing to get used to and are not explained well

• Game freezes/Lags/Crashes often


Relateable Games

ConclusionCastle Story has a great concept that has been executed poorly by the developers. It looks almost exactly the same from where it was on Kickstarter before it even came out, and the updates are more like patches. I would not reccomend this game to anyone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is currently not worth buying but the devs are trying to fix all the problems. Keep an eye on this game but don't buy it yet.

Edit:
Updates are slow and bare minimum. This game is probably never going to be playable. Even trying to leave the game on overnight to gather resources feels like a waste of electricity.

Edit 2:
As of December 7th 2015 this game is now playable. The AI is improved enough that Castles can be completed; however not the most efficient pathing. Survival was fun but lagged past playable when I reached the 6th wave on easy. My computer can run Fallout 4 (on High) so If yours can't then dont buy this. The game is at a stage where I feel it should have started for early access. I wouldn't recomend anyone looking for a serious strategy game to buy this but, if you want to support a very new development team who seems to be trying to complete this game despite multiple set backs Buy it. I think the average person could get 2 hours of fun. While I have played far more most of those hours I wish I could get back. Hopefully in the near Future I can finally, after years, switch to my review to a thumbs Up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brief:
Castle Story is my second biggest regrettable pruchase (looking at you, Starforge). This is supposed to be a fun castle builder in the essence of a tower defense game. I feel for the devs, but I can't help but dislike this game.

Pros:
+Has basic castle building mechanics
+Has basic resource mechanics
+Has very basic combat mechanics

Cons:
-Has the dev progress speed of a tortoise.. that doesn't have any legs..
-Has a wave game mode with no fast forward.. so slow..
-Each 'update' brings very little to the game, they seem to be more 'patches'
-Maps (think there are two now) are incredibly boring and feel empty
-Enemies are boring, with AI feeling very basic
-Friendly AI seem incredibly stupid and struggle with simple tasks
-I personally see literally no longevity to the game. It just goes on with no sense
of achievement whatsoever

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game was originally set to become a hit. There has been many delays since it originally released on the kickstart with many broken deadlines. It has been more than a year now since it's release and updates to the game *do* indeed happen, but they are sporadic and mostly about bug fixes.

The game modes currently in place don't have much to be joyful about. Survivor mode feels 'cheap', the enemies are just running towards you. As for the sandbox mode, it's much like Minecraft, ie you build stuff, but I feel like the addition of more 'building blocks' would make it a better experience.

The Dev Blog posts are almost void of any content and so the community still has no idea where this game is heading even after all this time.

Lack of updates, and lack of transparency of this game will ultimately kill it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now i dont mean to be a downer. I completely understand that there are only a small development team, ect, ect. but i bought this game over a year ago and i havent noticed any changes since i last saw it.

I honestly like the concept of this game and i dont mind the early access thing at al. However this game still has to reach the point where it is playable.

I wish the developpers all the luck in the world in their quest to finish this game but if one of my friends would ask me if he or she should buy this game then i would say: not yet. which is the same advice i give the reader of this review.

At the moment i cannot in good faith recommend this game to anyone. It is not playable at the moment and i fear that this will not change any time soon. If the developpers actually begin to make some notable progress on this game then i will be more then happy to adjust this review. But at the moment i have to say no...

I did notice that much of the progress on this game appears to be focussed on the engine. which is an understandable way of development. But at the same time there are ofcourse a lot of people who spend money on this game and dont know as much about programming and game design as proffesionals would. (completely understandable ofcourse) and those people are going to end up feeling cheated. hence my advice.

summary: Dont buy it. Keep it in your whishlist until it is finished and then buy it. Because the concept of the game is great and you are going to have a great time once it is playble. Castle story is scheduled for release in 2016 (as far as i know at least) so guys please keep this game in mind when that day comes

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Buy Castle Story? No, but why not? A 2 year summary

I'm watching the development since almost two years and played over 160 hours. Only survival mode because there are no other challanges. Sandbox mode didn't really interested me after all, you know minecraft?

Following Bugs and missing game options bother me since the first time i played. There has been changes and improvments but nothing got really fixed to a point im happy with. I guess a lot of other people feel the same after reading reddit and other sources, pointing out there's no progress would be wrong, but the prioritisation is amiss. I understand the process of prototyping, alphas and early access. But there shut be a noticable progress in all directions after two years of development.

- building menu - Castle Story uses some kind of nice circular menu, it has a nice appeal in the first place. But really nerves after using it, because its inconvenient. You need to do the following steps to choose one of your main building materials; 1x1 stone bricks: hold down the right mousebutton, the main menu appears, move the mouse to submenu button, release the right mouse button, the main menu disapperas. Press the right mouse button again, the submenu apperas, move to the 1x1 stone, release right the mouse button, now you can place your bricks. You know what!? Let me use the left mouse button to select the submenu and the 1x1 brick, this would make the following steps redundant and the selection would be; hold right mouse button, left click submenu, left click desired option, DONE!?

- blue Crystals - the Ore you need to gather for spawning new npcs is now stuck on stockpiles by default (version 0.3.3). This would be one of the very few added game mechanics in two years that made me happy, if turned off by default OMG. Now you have to manually order your broken Worker AI to carry the blue crystals to the main crystal or deaktivate the option on every stockpile you build... really?

- demolishing - you can't demolish stockpiles, lamps, barrels,... If it does work and i didn't realise how, why doesn't it work the same way it does with stones and wood. By the way, if it works with stones and wood, does it take why more than 2 years to implement this feature?

- zooming - nice to be able to zoom with the mousewheel, but only to a certain and low point. If users complain about that, they are told to use the old method, the caps key and mousewheel, now the can zoom infinite. What every sence restricting the mousewheel only zoom" and having two ways to zoom after all may have. Only one way to zoom
date:
problem fixed.

- Workers - still get stuck in many different tasks. I know theres a new AI and it's not implemented in survival mode yet. Currently (version 0.3.3) the AI is a killjoy.

- Swordsmen - useless as long as not standing in front of a gate. Because Enemys are past over before the realize there existence. Currently (version 0.3.3) the AI is a killjoy.

- Archers - commit suicide by shoting there bows and killed other player npcs

reviewText:
Early Access Review

THIS REVIEW IS IN PURGATORY: I'm working on writing a new one. On October 27, 2015 Sauropod Studios released Castle Story 0.5, which seems to be FULL OF CONTENT AND FEATURES. Time will tell if they will start releasing updates on a reasonable schedule, and it remains to be seen if the game will be finished. But read the review with an open mind; things are looking better than when I wrote it.

Original review:

This game cost me $20 USD or so, and gave me 113 hours of enjoyment. That's over five hours of play per dollar -- certainly more than I've gotten out of some AAA titles that cost me three times that much. It was a fun little game.

So why the thumbs down? Well, because despite being a somewhat *fun* game, it's not a *complete* game. And at this point it is not clear to me that the game will EVER be complete.

The devs posted this disclaimer long ago: http://www.sauropodstudio.com/steam-early-access-disclaimer/ stating the features that work and those that are planned. The disclaimer is pretty accurate, it doesn't lie about what's working and what's not. The problem is that the what's working" list has not grown by a single item since I bought the game -- litterally the ONLY feature of any note that has been added was a pause function -- which would have been greatly appreciated if I hadn't worn out the gameplay many months ago -- but they haven't made any visible progress towards that complete feature set they said they were planning.

Some of this is understandable. It's a young studio
date: this is their first game and the developers are less experienced than those on a lot of other games. They made some early mistakes and had to refactor the code base
recommended: which took a long time. Normally
hoursPlayed: refactoring (while frustrating for end users because it consumes time with no new features) is useful because it reduces future bugs and makes implementing new features later much easier. But these things only matter if you RELEASE UPDATES after the refactoring.\n\nAs I said
voteText: this is the studio's first game
helpfulPercent: and as you can see it's not going super well. It's entirely possible that they are out of money and about to go bankrupt for all I know. So it's impossible to say when or even if this game will get another update
votesHelpful: or if a hypothetical update would even contain any significant improvements.\n\nSo while it really boils down to the typical early access mantra of "Only pay for it if you are happy with the CURRENT state of the game"
votesTotal: and while the current state of the game WAS worth the money I paid for it
votesFunny: I can't really recommend this game because I know that most people are less easy to please than I am
commentsCount: and want a finished product. This game may never be that."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\n(Patch 0.6) Since the first beta, i try every new patch, and i've always been disapointed by the way everything was slow and unsteady. I think that this patch is a turning point. It was the first time that the game got hard, and it was fun like that. The Bricktrons now move with no hesitation, they build fast and the most impressive part :  the combats are now epic! The Minitrons are flying everywhere, most of the action is fluid, the pathfinding is fast and the AI look like it understand what is going on (they don't exaggerate when they say the pathfinding is 100X faster or more). Still, beware, this game is far from finish, but i have a good feeling about the upcoming releases. Bravo à toute l'équipe de Sauropod!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DO NOT BUY! Sauropod studios are run by a very small group of inexperienced, unapologetic jerks. If you bought in to this game through kickstarter or early access, they will treat you like crap on the forums.

The only thing Castle Story had going for it was the amazing work the Community Manager: Box, was doing. Box would try to give information to you straight, without breaking any of the company rules, which was very difficult to do. Box would always try to break information down to the community and calm people down who were angry about any of the situations. In the end, the company would give Box misleading information and then blame him for giving out any information to the community.

One of the primary developers for Castle Story is a dev named Thierry. Thierry has a tendency to berate the community for asking questions. On multiple occasions I've read post by him calling out individuals and virtually yelling at them, or the community in general and blaming them for being impatient. The game has been in development for years now, and there has literally been no visual improvement in over a year.

Originally there were weekly updates on what was going on, with an occasional skipping of a week or two. Now there are monthly updates on what is going on. I take that back. There are monthly video blogs about things nobody cares about. These monthly" video blogs have only made it up to the 3rd blog before they seem to have stopped posting them. It has been six weeks since the last video blog

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Castle Story is a castle building strategy game with delightful cartoonish graphics and a fun premise.
You order around a group of little yellow warriors, gathering resources and supplies to build a castle, to protect a large crystal that serves as a spawner for your units. All of this on the fairly simple-though-attractive backdrop of some flying islands in the sky.

Sadly, that's about where the charm of the game ends and the problems start to show up.

Charming though it may be, the game has multiple issues ranging from save-games not loading properly, to certain game modes not functioning. There are major slow-downs in the game, and often your AI will become stuck doing nothing, for seemingly no reason.

The beautiful structures you see in the screenshots are nearly impossible to build in the game's current state. (No, seriously, how in the heck did they make those?)

Development is also insanely slow, if it's even progressing at all.
Make no mistake, there is nothing even nearly complete about the game as it is now.

I want to like the game, it shows a lot of promise, and it LOOKS fun; but with issues that haven't been fixed in literally years, and no sign of forward movement, you're much better off saving your money for a different game.

IF things change in the future, I will happily update my review.

It's a great concept, really! But the developers seem to be incapable of getting the game running properly. Been following its development for years now, and while I'm aware I purchased an Early Access game,  it's at the point now where I don't see this game ever being finished.  It has the same bugs and lack of content it did a year ago, the units don't respond well (or sometimes not at all) to commands, there's still no solid multiplayer, and the game still lags tremendously after a certain amount of waves.. This game isn't going anywhere, sadly. Unplayable.

I strongly urge you not to buy this game.

Kerbal Space Program went through enough updates to go into Beta.
Prison Architect (smaller development team than Sauropod) had 10 major additions and 2 bug hunts.
Day Z (and in not a big fan of it) added cars along with a plethora of survival features and bugs.
Subnautica was released and has added two different vehicles and is ready to add two more zones.
and those are just the ones i own.

In a 12 month period Castle story has basically had one A.I. update and released their new big map". Even with these updates the game is still bugged to the point of being unenjoyable I hope something happens but as it stands

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was an original Kickstarter backer from about 3-years ago.  I was very disappointed in the development of new content prior to steam and for the past year I hadn't paid much attention to Castle Story until I happen to notice that 0.5 was released and appears to incorporate some new content.  I figured it had probably been a year or more since I last checked in so I'd give it another go.

Upon booting up the game, I noticed there were some new maps which made me think perhaps maybe they had finally gotten their act together and started producing content.

I started off chopping down some trees so I had a place to stockpile resources.  I had remembered from a year ago when I last played that they came up with a horrible horrible user interface.  News flash, it's still there and it's my opinion that they somehow managed to make it even more complicated.  I simply, without a doubt, absolutely hate the interface they've come up with.

After creating a few dozen zones to allow my minions to place resources, I decided to start doing some mining to collect rock/stone as well.  I sent off four of the five minion to work on the side of a hill while my remaining unit cleaned up the rest of the trees and made some barrels for later.

About 10 minutes later, all my miners went stupid and were just standing there.  I moved them away from the hill, then assigned them to mining the hill again, which they happily did until 5 minutes later when they went stupid and forgot what they were supposed to be doing again.

I instructed the minion away from the hill again, lets them regroup and sent them back to mining the hill again.  After 5 minutes, brain dead again.  Apparently the game still has some very serious pathing issues that have yet to be resolved.

Right click, delete local content.

I guess I’ll check back in a few years when 0.6 comes out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although in its current state it is a pretty interesting game, it will likely not change in the next few years. In two years, there has been two mentionable updates, both of which brought either tiny features, (such as pillars) game breaking bugs (such as the assumed memory leak in the unstable build which forces you to reload the level every ten minutes) or both.
I understand creating games is not easy, even through easy methods, such as game making or scripting programs, but this seriously makes me wonder if they are actually doing any development, or just making YouTube videos to say they are. I doubted Starbound, and they barely pulled through once, but this is far more problematic than slow development; this is avoidance.

My suggestion is to put it on your wishlist, wait about five years, and check again. By that time you will maybe know its fate.

I apologise for my straightforwardness.

Edit 09 08 (Aug) 15
The game in its current state is unplayably difficult. Using several different tactics I haven't been able to get past wave 4. The enemy is more powerful, spawns faster and has less chance of friendly-fire, and outnumbers you significantly. Time to go edit the map again, this is an interesting game if you can get past the lack of updates, the bugs (most of which are fixed more recently) and the now outrageous difficulty.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't do it! If you want to waste $20 on something worthwhile go buy banished or heck even get stonehearth or Don't Starve. It's been almost 3 years since this game came out! They surpass the time it took dota 2 to come out of beta. There is no hope that they plan on finishing this and can be reassuringly be declared a dead game. Like by time they finish it half-life 3 will have came out already. That's really slow if valve time is faster than an indie game development... And when i say valve time is faster I mean the developers are extremely slow ,incompetent and aren't willing to communicate with the community go on and read the other reviews it's the same thing over and over but if you want to know about the game besides the opinion review up there go to the next paragraph.

So what they have done in the past 3 years: the AI can barely function correctly, they let out an update once in a blue moon and usually it is the most unhelpful thing, They rarely actually fix anything besides make the problem worse, it has so much potential but with staff like this the game will probably never finish and it probably won't go the correct direction. If you want more reasons:
-multiplayer doesn't work
-the maps themselves suck and only 1 type of map is a survival map
-the other maps are buggy
-the AI stop for long periods of time or just stop completely
-the staff don't really solve any problems in the game
-literally it has been 2 years and nothing has really changed besides adding a pillar...
-the maps you can play and build are floating islands and your resources drop down there 50% of the time
-after xx waves the energy you are supposed to get randomly goes off into the bottom of the map and you never get the energy from them
-the developers probably stopped working on this game to pursue something else so it seems to give off the signal of an abandoned game.

I can go on and on about it so buy this game at your own risk, I am not saying it won't ever get better but if they keep on going this way then it will be safe to say the developers just want your money for half-♥♥♥ work and will probably drag it out as long as they can. You have been warned

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just don't buy this. There are thousands of better things to do with $20 than buying this game. Buying this game is the same as giving $20 to the begger on the street that leeches on working people and gets drunk every night. You gain nothing from giving them $20 and society gets nothing from giving them $20. Do not do it.

These guys don't work like you and I work for our boss. These guys are the kind that were making Duke Nukem Forever for 20years and still ended up with nothing.
It's very unlikely they are trying to make the game but are the most incompetent people ever. Very likely they are sitting around the office all day playing their Xbox and eating pizza. I don't know how they aren't disgusted with themselves but having millions of dollars from sales in your pocket probably helps a lot.

- The developers are so bad at their job that the first alpha released worked better than the first alpha they brought to Steam. And the current version on Steam works even worse than the first. The game development is going backwards. I know how crazy this sounds yet I'm saying the words with truth.
- All 3years of development so far have been a struggle with making the core of the game. Basic functions are still not completed and many features like remapping keys or full options screen or a working AI pathfinding are still not in the game.
They use Unity3D and all basic game features that you can imagine are nothing more than importing an asset store package and 15min configuration to build it into your own game. These guys fail at using a wizard that has 200 tutorial videos about on youtube. Literally!
Anyone with the capacity to work in a game engine can rebuild to the current state of the game within a month. I know.
- Their artist is working as hard as the rest of the team. All characters and props can be made in 2 weeks after viewing a few hours of Blender tutorials. Everything is modelled and textured extremely simple. You'd think after 3 years they would have more than 1 spruce tree, 1 yellow guy, 1 kind of grey rocks and 1 kind of wood beams/planks? You'd think there would be beaches and mountain ranges and dessert maps etc?
- About a year ago they must have noticed buyers were catching on to their scam. So they hired some guy to full time censor the forums and delete any negative thread and ban any user that speaks any kind of bad about the game. Meanwhile all the new buyers who still genuinly think this game will ever be finished get smoothtalked how busy everyone is and how they have plans to fix and remake everything. After months when that deadline has come and gone, they invent a new deadline.

TLDR: The people from Sauropod are scum.

If you don't believe me, just scroll down the reviews and you can see that nothing I am saying is a lie. These guys are scammers, will shut you up any way they can and Valve is so out of touch with their customers that they don't react to thousands of complaints.

I advise agaisnt buying this game (at least in its current state). It has been over 2 years since I purchased this game and there has been no new content added aside from temporary holiday bits. I suggest waiting for the full game if it ever happens. Over the course of the last 2 years, Castle Story has just recently claimed it will add a new map. Yes, 2 years for a map (and it isn't even available as of writing this). This game has potential, but the developers are not delivering. To help understand, here is a complete list of what has been accomplished with the game (minus bug fixes and balancing) for the past 2 years. Note, Everything on these lists are taken directly from each company's respective patch notes and version histories. I compare Castle Story to KSP and Prison Architect to quantify it. See Spoiler below. I can't help but feel Sauropod is following a non-production business model.



Asset = significant addition / change to game play
UI = Change / addition to user interface to help with current assets
Aesthetic = Game Polish / Visual / Audio only
Technical = Change to game performance (but not game play)

Over the last 2 years:

I was excited for this game from the moment i heard about it, i was one of the first to jump on the initial kick starter in 2012. when I got the 1st release of the game later in 2012 it was pretty much unplayable... and I am sad to say after 3 years of development not much has changed.
The controls are clunky and fickle making building anything somewhat complex a constant fight. the AI is just terrible, they cant seem to do anything on their own with out you micro managing them to make sure they dont get stuck. there is no real content in the game yet, no real point to playing(unless a constant battle with controls and poor AI is what you find fun). I had high hopes for this game and maybe one day it will be great, but at its current rate it will not be anything worth playing for another several years :(

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After backing this game based on its promise, it has turned out to be a huge disappointment thanks to the continous bugs and the complete and total lack of anything even vaguely resembling progress.

Every time I find myself of a mind or in a mood to play it, I go and look for updates only to find they have at best released a handful of minor bugfixes, usually for bugs they created with their last major patch. No new content, no new levels, none of the mechanics that were originally promised, nothing. No multiplayer, no story mode, no maps or map editor...

And I'm not talking about every few days or even weeks. This is totally the type of game I really WANT to play, it seemed like it had the potential. Originally, I *did* check up on it on a regular basis. But after continous disappointment, particularly when I *would* see an update on Steam and get my hopes up, only to find it was nothing of interest... I lost interest. Now several months go by before I even bother, and yet, still then, there's nada. Nichts. Zilch.

And my interest in the game, despite it's potential, despite the fact that it SHOULD be the kind of game I'd love, my interest is basically the same as the game's development pace, which is to say, next to non-existent. Actually, the very fact that it has inspired me to go out of my way to write what is for me a rare negative review should say it all. I have no idea what they do over there at Sauropod Studios, but it most certainly isn't anything remotely like what I'd call work"
date: I can only assume that they've happily taken the $700k they made off the Kickstarter and are laughing at us all the way.\n\nEDIT: The developers CLAIM the game will be "released" at the end of the year. IF that happens and we actually get what we were promised in the Kickstarter
recommended: I will revist this review at that time. Until then
hoursPlayed: I simply cannot recommend this game based on the progress we have seen in the 3 years since it was supposed to release in the first place."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nMy complete thoughts on this title. Basically, castle story is a very unique game that has a ton of potential. Although people beleive its very similar to games like towns, its completely different. Altough the objective of castle story is to protect your base from ememys and buils structues, its thought on survival is really weak, There're no food or water meters for your little minions, and the whole idea of 'crafting' is completely useless. Despite this, the game is actually fun to play, but can only be played for short amount of hours at a time, as its very repetative. Its area of land is also very small and limited, but as i said, it can be fun to play, and its still in Early Access, so what can you expect? So, is this game worth $20? Probably not, if im honest. Although fanboys may disagree, and cliaming that 'its only in early development and more will come', we should really expect more from these types of games, expecially if people are laying down $20 for a game that could have been made by a college student. Overall, if you're on the wall with this game, save the cash, and wait till more has been added. Not much to do, and not much fun overall. Infact the only thing that will keep you playing is the graphics.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After a year or so of not playing Castle Story, I recently came back to it and soon ran into a new patch which broke the game for me. I decided to wait a few weeks for them to fix it — the one that froze the game with constant lag after about an hour and a half of playing the same map, and when you reach a certain number of people. Over a month later, there is still no fix.(As of the 26th of June, I have tested the latest patches... it's still going on)

When I add that situation to how long this game has taken in the past, until now, to actually have updates implemented, I have to give this one a rather big no for my recommendation. This game has so much potential, and I mean a lot, but there is definitely an issue with the very slow development team, and the lack of progress made when an update is actually released — not much has actually been implemented long term, and important parts of the game are still disabled by the developers because they don't work properly (such as digging).

I follow a lot of early access games and this is the poorest development cycle I am aware of at the moment.

Negatives (As of June 2015 with 'bleeding edge' version)
-The way the UI is set-up for building, placing items, etc, is atrocious. You have to drill down through so many selections to reach what you want to reach, then you have to get back out if you want to do something else.. it's a bit like torture.  (This is the worst thing about the game for me)
-The Save/Load menu is bulky, and slow to use. This needs polishing. (small issue though)
-Very slow progression with the development of the game
-The radius with cutting down trees. You have to keep adding 'flags' every time you want to cut down a group of trees, and this is rather tedious.
-Major performance issues when reaching a certain number of people on screen
-The way blue crystal is put into crates by default (again, tedious to manually move it to the actual blue crystal)
-The lack of maps on survival. There needs to be a variety here based on peoples play styles, such as a corner start, instead of in the middle. This would greatly improve the game for a lot of people.
-The waves(enemies) come too fast. There needs to be an option to manage waves before beginning the game
-The fact you have to place a clean up broom radius flag… they should just clean up automatically, or the stuff that needs cleaning up should disappear over time. (tedious to manage, and the little bits littering the ground slow the game down)

Positives (As of June 2015 with 'bleeding edge' version)

-Friendly fire, but this can get annoying (needs fine tuning)
-Variety of enemies (needs fine tuning)
-The types of structures you can build using stone or wood. This is rather fun and is really the main point of the game.
-The cuteness of the game. The yellow guys and the grey guys are all very cute and make cute noises.
-Having your archers take out the enemy is rather enjoyable once you have enough of them, and a system in place where you know exactly where to place them, and how to build your defences.
-The quick response of the developers to forum posts is very supportive & commendable
-The music is quite good, but there needs to be more variety.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I saw Castle Story on Kickstarter back in 2012 and wished I could have kick-started it, the concept was new and interesting, the graphics looked fresh and pretty and it looked like a fun game that would go somewhere. Well, 4 years down the line it still looks exactly like it did 4 years ago on that Kickstarter page.

As far as I see, there is no real 'gameplay' to it other than plan a castle, dig some quarry's or mines and then watch the little yellow dudes AI fail to get it them the build zone or even properly drop resources off.

Instead, you'll spend your game time watching your workers swap resources around with one another rather than building anything. It almost seems like they tried to implement a bucket brigade AI... which would work great if they gave the poor little workers a little more logic so they didn't run the exact same path when on the same task - because they then spend more time swapping resources between themselves and 'finding paths to blueprint' instead of running over there.

The problems around building make it really hard to even attempt the 'wave survival' game modes - because its takes so long to get a simple wall around it and the damage enemies do (even on easy) wipes out your meagre combat units really quickly (I survived 60 kills ~8 waves before losing but still didn’t even have a simple wall up because the yellow dudes couldn't decide or work out how to get places)

The final straw for me was putting 6 workers on a large build task. They'd keep stopping at the build site, even though there were plenty of resources and lots of room for movement. They just all kept saying they were going to the same pile of resources which I can only assume meant all 6 of their poor little AI's were clashing and blocking one another... without anyone actually moving!

Some bullet points of what bugged me the most (Version 0.5.1):

- The UI is terrible. Every action in-game relies on a right click and hold - it's not intuitive, it’s not clear and it’s not even explained to you. I had to go find a video tutorial on basic camera movement and building because it was so annoyingly unclear. Actions should speak for themselves and not have to be searched for.

- Speaking of UI, sorting what materials can be placed on a storage pad is ridiculous. If you want to make it specifically wood, it takes 5 right click, hold, and selects to set it so. You need a lot of storage, so multiply that by the number of space you want... it’s just plain silly.

- For a game about building castles its surprising tedious to build anything in (let alone a castle), you need more workers to get things done faster but the more workers you have the slower the build goes because they spend time bumping into one another and sometimes they just decide to have a stop work meeting.

- The game constantly lags and has miniature seizures for a few seconds every few seconds...

- As outlined, the AI is just shoddy. There are a few simple things that would make it miles more efficient... the best being a complete overhaul of their path-finding algorithm and how they interact with one another (not swapping resources every damn time they bump into each other!)

- The game could benefit from a 'speed up time' button... a lot.

Overall: 3/10

Just so much wasted potential.

Avoid at all costs - don't be fooled! There are better games out there!

Early Access Review

Castle Story has potential to be a pretty cool game, unfortunately it looks more and more like that will never happen.  Development is painfully slow, I think maybe the devs just get together once a month for a few hours.  They just keep redoing the same features over and over, never getting it right or even making any noticeable difference.

As it stands at the time of this review (and probably for several months to come) the game has very little to offer.  One playthrough of survival will probably be all you need to see everything there is.  As far as creative mode, there are much better sandbox games out there that are much less frustrating in ways a game should not be frustrating (pathing, glitches, etc).

Maybe come back in a couple years and see if they've made any progress toward doing this idea justice, but don't bother buying it now.  They've had more than enough time to deliver but they're not even trying.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is nearly unplayable due to bugs that should have been dealt with three years ago. At it's core, Castle Story is an experimental survival/sandbox RTS in which you tell little yellow guys called Bricktrons what to do. They can work or fight, but typically get confused while carrying out their assigned tasks and just stop doing anything. The bugs in this WiP game are just too much, considering the fact that it's been 'in beta' for four years now. The project is obviously too much for the 10-man, part-time, on-again-off-again development team, and it's gotten to the point that they've hired on a PR guy to try in vain to dispel the rumors that this game has crumbled to nothing. Updates are infrequent, and the ones that come every four to six months add no new content, and fix none of the bugs which make the game almost unplayable. Box, if you're reading this, I'm sorry for you, and what the company you're representing is doing to you, and to the Kickstarter backers of this game. 1/5

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've owned this for over like 3 years and I backed it in the Kickstarter and had super high hopes for Castle Story but I felt really ripped off when I finally got to play the 'early access'. It looked absolutely nothing like in the trailers or demos that we were given a lot of previews of. I followed development really closely and I felt like the dev team at times were really ignorant of how the players felt about their 'progress' and 'attention' on certain aspects of the game.

I made a thread on the forums with over 15 things that I could not find in the early access version of the game, vs all the demo videos they had shown. In the end I got the response I was expecting. Nothing.
In the beginning you were actually advised by the devs to enable the cheats console to even use the game properly.
Certain sounds were bugged so badly like background 'crickets' that were looped really loudly and never stopped and couldn't be silenced without muting the whole game.
Entire 'building bricks' that were in the demos were missing. These were small things that were missing for ages.
There were no enemies for close to a year.
The menu, even years after the early access was released, is still terrible and so unintuitive.
For 2 years after the game was available to play, there wasn't any multi-player at all.
It took a year just to get the choice to start off on a different map from that only single one the game shipped with.
Development blogs and transparency from the devs went from being something they would write about and share with their players weekly, to where you wouldn't hear from them for months despite people paying for early-access (funding them).
AI was so bugged and 'bricktons' would just randomly stop what they were doing or get stuck so easily.
Performance on a good machine was absolutely terrible for over a year.
All in all, for the amount of money they raised on Kickstarter and the speed at which they went to early access, the game was one of the most disappointing in its early stages, that I had ever seen. In the end this game in particular taught me to never purchase an 'early-access' game because the sheer lack of development progress the game can be on, and still be allowed to be released on Steam is just ridiculous.

I really wanted to like this game, but I feel that development has shifted so many times due to the incompetent team. Also in mid 2015 almost no one plays this game. All Youtube videos are from 2-3 years ago when the game still had some 'hype' let alone some 'hope' surrounding it. Little has changed since then except that now the game has less bugs and could be considered something that doesn't need to be in 'early access'. This doesn't change the fact that the game simply isn't fun for me, and that the controls and UI and menus are still terrible. Basically the developers have totally missed their deadline in terms of it getting popular.

It's not remotely worth €25 and it probably won't be for another 2 years. It's a huge shame too because the graphics and potential this game has is absolutely through the roof. Hopefully in a few more years I will be able to recommend it, that is, if development is even on going and if people even play it.

P.S. I know my review isn't very 'consistent' but you can't expect that when development on this game has been about as inconsistent as it gets.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was very excited for this game. I was actually convinced to buy this game a year ago because a friend had it and wanted to try the multiplayer. We tried forever to get the mutiplayer to work but it never did and the devs eventually locked it and now its been like that for a long time. I never wrote a review about the game because I hoped it would get better. It never did. The game is still plauged with problems and has been in early access for at least a year and a half. That seems like plenty of time to actually get something done, right? Nope. I noticed almost no difference in the game when I played today in comparason to the day I bought it (End of 2013) The only things that seemed different were that they had iron and annoying curruptions that took forever to kill. The game still feels like a buggy mess when I play. Constantly my workers glitch and stop working or listening to commands. Ive seen them complain that they cant reach blocks right in front of them. They bunch up in 2 block wide hallways and I constantly have my guys shot by archers. My warriors dont listen and attacking is annoying because its hard to click on the guy you want to kill. Sometimes guys stand there and die because they glitch out. Some glitches have to be fixed by reloading the save and gets annoying when you have to do it every 30-60 minutes. The game also suffers from screen tearing. My NVEDIA 880M and Intel I7 4710HQ@3.50GHz have trouble running this game because the game refuses to use them to their full power. The highest ive seen my GPU usage go in this game is 40% and the CPU 50%. Mostly the game uses around 10-20% of my GPU and 30-40% of my CPU and my ram hovers around 9GB (Out 0f 32) Since the game refuses to use my gpu or cpu the framrate is terrible. When I get into a game the framerate is great. But it quickly drops and then hits around 1-2 FPS with gpu usage at 1-10% and CPU at 10-20%. I know you have to click the delete key but even then the game hovers around 30-40FPS with 20-30% gpu usage and 30-40% cpu usage. I dont have a cap on frames either. In an attept to fix the screen tearing I lowered the graphics to fastest and went to NVEDIA control panel and turned on VSYNC. Frame rate was still the same even though my GPU was 1-10% and CPU was still 20-30%. On my old computer I had in 2013 (It had a NVEDIA 230M and an I7 cpu with 8GB of ram) the framrate never went below 120FPS and stayed near 200FPS when the game started and I had full GPU and CPU usage. It seems to me that this problem has come recently. The sreen tearing is ugly and basicallyis the final nail in the coffin for this game. Most of the graphical problems arrise when the GPU usage goes down to below 20%. Setting the game to High Priority does not even help. My GPU is not crap either. For some perspective I can run GTA 50FPS with everything at very high except water (High) and shadows (High) with MSAA on and tessalation off. My resolution is 2560X1440p tooso its quite impressive and the game looks great. When playing GTA gpu usage is at 98% and CPU is at 70-90%.

In short the graphical problems come when the GPU is used at its lowest and I could ignore the bugs if it wasent for the horrendus screen tearing and FPS that slowley drops over time. What sucks even more is that when you join a world at wave 10 the framrate starts at 60 and then drops to 10-20 over a period of 2 minutes and its not because there is stone everywhere. I constantly remove the stone by hitting delete.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Castle Story was a fun concept tied around a modestly appealing, simplistic art style. And before anybody locks to this review for being negetive, let me explain. I don't dislike this game, but it's simply under-developed and shows very little ammounts of progress. The cons far out way the pros, but I will be more than happy to change this review once it finishes. (IF it finishes.)

Pros:
-Voxel system
-Cool graphical style
-It's like if Minecraft was simplified and made into an RTS

Cons:
-The AI is dreadfuly stupid
-Path finding is about as bad as you could get without the bots standing completely still (which they will often do)
-Optimization? This game, even on the lowest graphical settings, will at random, draw to a halt. Freezing and stuttering like your computer is a toaster
-Lots of bugs, unresponsive AI, can't cut down a tree without it tumbling off the side of the map into oblivion, ect
-It's like if Minecraft was simplified and made into an RTS

I really do wanna see this game get further along, but such a slow development process is leaving me with little hope it'll ever get out of early access. (Although multiplayer was finally added in recently.) I won't hold my breath for this game.

TL:DR early access at its finest. 4/10

(PS: Could be a good 5-6 as is were the AI not so bad.)
(PPS: To the developer: Please work on this. It's a great concept, and shouldn't be left to die.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It pains me to write this, especially as one who managed to get some enjoyment out of this title, as well as someone who bought the game barely a month after it was put up on Steam with high hopes. Castle Story is a lackluster and at times needlessly frustrating experience that will just make you want to crave more with no hope of it ever delivering. First of all, the AI remains dirt stupid and at times unresponsive, making mutlitasking, an element crucial to games like these, more arduous than it should be. Sandbox mode will most likely not hold your attention for long, with there being a limited variety in building materials. Not only that, but getting said materials is time consuming and tedious, something you don't want said about a supposed sandbox mode.

Survival mode seemed promising at first, combining the freedom to build structures of many shapes and sizes with a tower defense play-style. Now, there is fun to had here if you're willing to look past the bad AI and hardly any strategy. Otherwise, the novelty won't save it from the mediocrities riddled throughout this gamemode. Accompanied with the aforementioned AI problems, the guards will ignore oncoming enemies, letting them slip by and wreak havok on your settlement. It's a shame because this gamemode has the potential to be something fufilling, if it were just executed better and had more options at your disposal (i.e, leveling up bricktrons and contraptions, stronger materials, depth in level design).

With no other gamemode to fall back on, you are almost guaranteed to lose interest long before this ever leaves early-access. You'd think that the developers would have found the time to encorporate more features and gamemodes in the last two years or so to keep us interested, much like many other open-alpha indie games out there. But alas, for whatever reason, updates have mainly consisted of bug fixes and graphical improvements. Unless by some miracle, this game gets finished and has a solid, replayable, and satisfying experience as a final product, I doubt I'll be concerning myself with this game anytime soon, and I suggest you do the same, to anyone thinking of buying this.

I've been playing it off and on since it came out and have logged quite a number of hours. I keep checking back in because I LOVE the idea and style. But the average person is definitely going to stop playing after a couple of frustrating games and that seems like a waste of money.

2 years, and very little has improved. All the in-your-face bugs are still there. Some of the less annoying ones have been fixed but very few of them.

It leads me to believe that the developers are simply incapable of fixing these bugs. If they were able to do it, it would have happened by now. But the potential of this game should not be wasted. Therefore, someone needs to steal this great idea and build a game that actually works. I'd donate big to a kickstarter to a dev who would run with this idea.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You never know what you are going to get when you buy into an Early Access game. Sometimes you help fund the next gem of a game, like Prison Architect, who probably wouldn't have had the capital to make such a game if it weren't for EA, but on the other hand, sometimes your money gets flushed into the eternal purgatory that is commonplace in EA and you never get your money back, The Dead Linger.

Castle Story feels more like The Dead Linger side of the EA. No, the makers haven't thrown in the towel yet, but there really hasn't been much improvement in the past year, content or performance wise. I honestly hope that I am wrong, and if that is the case, if they finish this game with a stable, playable, fun state, I will change this review, but at the moment, I could not and would not recommend this game to anyone.

For the first half of my time spent on this game I found myself restarting over and over gain because the building system is flawed, there is no way to undo specific bricks in walls if you make a mistake as far as I can discern and placing even one single brick in the wrong place while laying foundations means that you have to do the whole thing over again. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun castle building, can't be all too bad, right? - Hint - YES

Building is fine, AI is bad, it is so bad you can have archers killing themselves.

You can have your footmen stand 5 tiles away from an enemy as it tears down your castle walls.

Sometimes your footmen will run to the opposite side of a large castle to kill an enemy while another enemy is pounding your walls down.

Workers panic and drop everything when the enemy is not even close to them.

Build order is whatever spot is closest to them, not where you place the block first.

Game hasn't had a meaningful update in over a year.

Not recommended.

Early Access Review

The low productivity is unfortunately all to clear.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Castle Story has been in development for well over a year and in that time not a large amount of progress has been made. However with that being said I believe there is real promise with this game, all be it if it gets finished! There are some things which make it very unique and some which make it mainstream.

Pros:

- Unique Art Style
- Interesting style of gameplay
- Enjoyable for Short - Medium play times (1-3 Hours)
- Survival is very promising

Cons:

- Quite buggy in terms of the AI (AI often gets stuck with overloaded orders and enemy can often find pathing difficult)
- Variety of units is very limited (Melee Warrior/Archer/Builder:Unarmed)
- Limited Gamemodes
- Very basic Tutorial (Controls are very simple but was lack of proper tutorial, can be frustrating)
- Limited building options (2x2 Block | 1X1 Block | Arch Block | Wooden Pillar | Wooden Plank)
- Time period of development is worrying (Over a year and not a large amount of progress)
- Pricing (£15/$20) Is very constly for an almost Alpha/Beta

Overall the game is fun to play for a Short/Medium amount of time however given the number of issue's addressed above  I would hold off buying it untill there is improvement or unless it is discounted down to around £4-8/$12. However because of these issues I would have to rate it probably a 4/5 out of 10!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI want to write a good review for this game, I really do. When i bought it i had hoped for a great system to build castles and defend against sieges. Dont get me wrong, make a half decent AI system and ill gladly re-write this review. But they havn't done that. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've had this game since April of last year and still can't get it to work how it was supposed to intentionally.

Quick list of negatives:
- The AI are unresponsive and take so much patience - and in a mode such as survival, you cannot afford the sometimes minutes it takes for some AI to 'think'.
- Updates are almost nonexistant, I returned just today after a few months of not playing just to see the changes equivalent to that of a single update in a 'normal' game.
- Multiplayer is barren. I have yet to find any servers, and I feel this is more a fault of the developers rather than the community with the huge negative feedback they have received.
- Recently, the tutorial seems to be absent.

Quick list of positives:
+ The GUI is really beautiful - all so clean cut and accessible, with features within are organized wonderfully.
+ A great concept, I think, especially for PvP or co-op multiplayer gameplay. Altough I've never seen PvP, or any multiplayer mode for that matter, the idea sounds wonderful.
+ A great selection of different building pieces, opening a wide range of possible constructs to defend your 'Bricktrons'.

This game is something I think everyone that came here wanted to badly to love; I denied the numbers of negative reviews when I purchased the game, but honestly I don't believe it was a mistake. Although, that may just be my want to love it talking.

If I ever see any actual involvement of the developers, I might recommend it. Just don't forget about this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am truly saddened by what happened to this game.
Before I begin, allow me to state that I understand the risks of purchasing an Early Access game. I am able to excuse a ♥♥♥♥ load of bugs and issues and I'm able to accept that this is by no means a finished product. But there's a difference between a game in development and an absolute blatant scam.

Castle Story is a game about constructing a base and defending from wave after wave of onslaughting enemy hordes. A fairly basic and enjoyable mechanic that has worked before and is enhanced by a unique artstyle, soundtrack, voxel system and physics engine. To be honest I really did enjoy Castle Story for a few hours until I found out that there's no variety in enemy units, no upgrading my own units and that there's really just not a whole lot to do. You build a castle and that's fine for a few hours, then you wander off and do Sandbox things for a few hours and then you realize that's about it. Again, I understand that it's early access and I shouldn't expect that much in the first place, and to be fair the game does deliver on its initial promises, but sadly it just sort of falls short. But that's not the fault in this game.

The developers of this game are a team known as Sauropod Studios" a fitting name considering their contributions all but died out some time ago. Sauropod is the reason the game industry is failing. They are (or were) what I call a "Smash and Grab" Developer

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TLDR: Looks can be deceiving.

At the time of writing, the game is only early access.  As usual, you shouldn't expect too much - the game will be glitchy and buggy, and my opinion of the game takes that into account.

Castle Story is basically another sandbox dwarf-fortress-ish game that appears to take a different approach by using much simpler game mechanics.  You don't have to worry about needs such as food and water, but rather just focus on building a functional castle that can defend against attacks.

What I like

- It looks cool!  It's got the puffy white clouds, the very simple-looking avatars (bricktrons), the lego-like castle building blocks, etc.,
- The gameplay is very simple, it has a refined-looking design, something that appeals to me.

What I don't like

- Although being early-access, the game is barely playable.  I tried really hard to enjoy the game, but couldn't.  I fully expect to find bugs in a beta, but this title is mostly all looks, the gameplay itself is very bad.
- There's not much to do in the game - when I say there's not much to do, I mean what you see in those screens is about it.  You can build some stone and wood blocks, and that's about it.

This game shouldn't be early access - it should've stayed out of Steam until it was much more ready than this.  The vibe I got after playing is that the developers - while they might mean well - are an inexperienced group desperately reaching for what funding they can get.

Here's a good discussion thread for more info.  I came back to it recently to find it locked - which seemed quite unnecessary.  This is another bad sign imo:
http://steamcommunity.com/app/227860/discussions/0/648814844593898025/#p10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

SUBJECT TO CHANGE


I've owned the game since at least October of last year, there have been few updates with no estimate of an official release. And prior to my purchase the game had been in pre-release status for I don't know how long, but apparently a decent amount of time. For a game that has so little to offer in terms of complexity it would be expected that the developers would work on cleaning up the code that they have to avoid lag build up from poorly constructed AI pathing loops, intense overlapping light bloom effects, and poor enemy spawning management (massive instant spawn of 1+ incrementing enemies that increase for each wave, each with their own poorly constructed pathing AI in a big mess of how long does it take your processor to figure out which one moves first). The development team seems to focus on cleaning up minor bugs and slowing down the process by adding new members to the team before they've even come close to working out game breaking kinks.

As a warning by wave 100 or sooner this game will be nearly unplayable (due to FPS) for people without an average or above average computer, even on fastest graphics settings. Avoiding torches and lighting may help with some FPS drop.

Granted the game is fun. Anyone that has no issues with repetitive gameplay and likes the concept of a kind of cross between RTS and Tower Defense games will probably enjoy this. Building a castle or structure that is tactical as you decide how you want to go about surviving increasing waves is pretty rewarding for people who would enjoy that, and the game offers a sandbox mode for players who don't want the interruptions that come with survival.

Overall, the gameplay is good, but it almost feels like the development team doesn't intend to actually finish the game. Like people who run off with scholarship money, this is starting to feel like a scam to half make a game with lots of kinks, slowly update little stuff, and then run off after sales start falling. Not that it is, but this has to be the laziest studio I've ever waited for. It doesn't even have a game icon.



Edit: RE: Developer comment and update.

I have already, and that doesn't change the length of time that has and still is going into the project. Not to mention that the game is still poorly constructed. I just finished actually playing the update, it was cut short by me not being able to pause. By that I mean I had to save my game to go to the bathroom. Tried to load it and there's a fresh new bug that kills saves. Archers still friendly fire and destroy storage areas, the AI pathing is choppy and inefficient, and it seems like corners were cut by making workers able to move through storage instead of fixing the AI itself. Now I don't know if that was the intention because frankly I enjoy the playability of the change, it does boost player efficiency because the workers don't dogpile anymore. However, for many months and obviously before I bought the game all of the entities seem to suffer from intense short term memory loss and they just stand there day dreaming in a programming loop. This is persisting even after this new update and every update before it.

My comment was harsh because this legitimately is the longest I've ever waited for a developing team to work out game breaking kinks, and I am going to remain harsh because so far the most noticeable changes have been graphical goodies for the seasons, a sound update, and minor bug fixes. There is nothing to re-evaluate, I'm a programmer too. If this were my project I'd address the major issues before working on redoing the sounds and giving people some holiday textures.

To not be unfair in this I will say that the changes made the game a much better experience. Being able to store more orange crystal and not have the dogpiling issue is nice. It does free up time. The change to gatherers defaulting to the storage space with the most material already in it is noticeable.

Now I have asked on the forums for some information about when certain issues are going to be fixed or if they are being taken into consideration. I didn't make this or my previous comment without giving a fair chance. I have been previously active on the main forum. I noticed a moderator that has a spider for a profile picture that gives people a hard time that aren't breaking any forum rules, and repetitive game complaints and suggestions that get little to no official response.

For more information read comments:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of the latest patch, this is now a game. Using systems similar to Towns, Gnomeria, and Dwarf Fortress, you command your little yellow dudes to build castles, brick by brick, to defend against random monsters as you try to conquire floating islands. It's pretty simplistic but if you enjoy the Dwarf Fortress game type combined with base defense mechanics, this game will scratch an itch. It's still early stages but it has a lot of potential.

It's rather unfortunate this game has so many negative reviews. It's in Early Access for a reason, the developers needed a lot of help to figure out in which direction the game should go to appeal to a bigger audience. As of the latest patch, the game is much better than it's ever been. I could actually understand most of the negative reviews for the earlier versions but, seriously, the game deserves a second chance. This is just another showing of how the Steam review system doesn't operate properly for Early Access games.

I backed this game when it first started it's kickstarter. It seemed great. I even went so far as to become a part of the forum and write a couple wiki articles and get to know a lot of people there.

Was it worth it? No.

I was a firm believer in the game, and I still think it has the potential to become something but it hasn't. I kept checking and checking on the game to see if it got better and if the bugs (mostly the ♥♥♥♥ing camera) were fixed. No. Nothing was fixed. No tutorial, not a thing. I wasted my money and my time for something that wasn't accomplished. I had problems with the codes I recieved and it took a very long time to fix that problem that, and honestly, I don't even know if it got fixed because the person I bought the second code for doesn't even want the game anymore.

I understand as a friend of game developers that these things take time. But 1 year and pre-alpha bugs are still not fixed but they're adding in new content? Focus on what is hurting your game. Focus on your community that you promised a great game to; instead of focusing on people that kept popping in and suggesting new content.

A rename to flying island simulator 2014 might suit it well until saur fixes it to the CASTLE STORY kickstarter game it was hyped to be. I should've donated that money to Root's ♥♥♥♥ing Reading Rainbow instead of having all this trouble.
voteText: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I know the thought process that goes behind buying a game like this. It LOOKS great, and it's only early access, so you're sure it's probably going to be great at some point. You've read negative reviews, and ignored them anyway. I did the exact same thing. I wish I had not.

This game is an awesome concept. It has the potentially be beautiful, fun, and worth the money that I just wasted. But right now, it's hardly even qualified to be a Beta game. It's a mess, and I'm highly discouraged by the rate at which it is being updated. This game is essentially unplayable as-is, as it becomes very boring very quickly.
As a game developer myself, I know how hard it is to create a working game, and how annoying it is when the audience does not understand all the work that must be put in to the final product. In this case, though, I feel like progress is practically inching along at the slowest pace possible, and a bug-ridden, unplayable, broken game was released to say 'Don't worry, we're doing something'.

I cannot recommend purchasing this game right now. My advice is to keep an eye on it, because it's an awesome idea and it has so much potential (potential which it had better reach, given the 700k that was donated to it via Kickstarter), but you'll be disappointed if you blow your Steam budget on the current stage of this game (as of 1/2/2014)
