reviewText:
Early Access Review

*Edit Jan '16*
Played the game for the first time in almost 13 months. The user interface somehow got considerably more obtuse and unintuitive, and the AI seems worse. I didn't encounter any of the performance issues many other people seem to have, but the game has become more difficult to play, and considering the time elapsed since my last playing, the lack of actual progress on the game is staggering.

*Edit Jan '15*
The devs have slowly been releasing the odd patch here and there for a month or two now, though not a lot has changed in terms of major bug fixes or progression of the game mechanics. However, hope has been rekindled for this game's future. Keep your eyes peeled.

---

I cannot in good conscience recommend this game.

I have played it for a considerable amount of time, and buggy as it is, I thoroughly enjoy what content exists so far. I honestly believe that many of the complaints against this game are simply coming from people who don't understand the game mechanics, convoluted and contrived though some of them may be. And despite its actual faults, I think the game has great potential.

That being said, the development appears to be dead. I had been giving the devs the benefit of the doubt for a long time, but that patience is wearing out. I have not played the game for almost a year now, and from what I gather from the forums, and reading the exceptionally rare patch notes"
date: nothing whatsoever has changed. And nothing had changed for a considerable amount of time prior to me beginning playing the game. I didn't expect this game to be complete because it's Early Access. I didn't, however, expect anything which was being sold to be this incomplete.

It's very buggy and there is no purpose to it what so ever. It's not like Minecraft or Terraria because you can't discover or craft. You can collect wood, stone, blue stuff and orange stuff. You can VERY slowly build castles and kill boring enemies which run at you at any given time.

In short, this game is boring, buggy and I regret buying it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are a lot of reviews that are negative but the vast majority of these address the game in its former state. This review is for the 0.6 Update. Remembering that this game is still in an Early Release state you should expect bugs, glitches, incomplete functions, and less features than a full game. All disclaimers aside I played the game for about an hour tonight and for the first time in several years I finally feel like the game has progressed somewhere. This most recent patch added new gameplay modes and fixed the most gamebreaking bugs that have been around forever (the AI and AI pathing algorithms causing Bricktrons to become stuck doing nothing and unwilling to take any further commands). During the hour of play tonight I ran across no bugs and the longest it took any Bricktron to understand my commands and obey was about 2-3 seconds. Compared to the hours in the past where they would just stand around this is a HUGE improvement. Further, none of them decided to suicide themselves off the side of the island.

In it's current state I see many further updates will be needed to complete the game, yes, however it's finally at a point where I can start playing it and enjoy the game. I'm headed to bed now but I'm excited about waking up early to continue my save where I left off tonight. That's a first for me on this game.

Updated Review, 0.5

Game has improved, but still lacks clarity in how it works.  Little minion dudes now listen to you much better, and attempt to follow through with commands, but they still get stuck.  Often they pile up at a resourse or just on top of each other trying to get something done, and they refuse to move around each other to get things going again.

Also, they aren't very competent at building, either.  Tried to have them flatten some land, only to have them keep trying to place a block that would just dissappear.  Also tried to start placing stone blocks, but the guy would only pickup dirt and then say he couldn't use it there.

It is getting updates, so it's not been abandoned... but right now there isn't any reason to buy it unless you are genuinly interested in being part of alpha development.  There is a lot of promise... once this game actually works, but for now, I advise just holding off.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game in February of 2014, and it has come a long, long way since that time. I remember buying a copy, and buying another copy for a friend of mine, and we both were very impressed with the functionality and gameplay straight off the bat. Early on, it was a little rough around the edges, but seeing as the devs are keeping it updated and adding more and more as time goes on, I have no doubt it will keep getting better and better. The multiplayer is pretty cool, fairly functional with a few small bugs, but I'm going to chalk those up to be the fact that my friend was hosting the server in Michigan and I was connecting from Arizona. The bugs I mentioned were buildings popping in and out of existance, Bricktrons popping in and out of existance (both of these item popping into and out of existance bugs reset after a server restart. Nothing ingame was lost.), and crashes occationally when my friend would stop the server.

As of right now, 05,16,2016, the multiplayer gameplay is a little bland. There's not much to do other than try to make cool castles and watch as bricktrons dig their way into the ground, then eventually seal themselves in their own mines. There is no PVP combat yet with the warriors, but you can still lop arrows at your friend's worker bricktrons when he sends them over to your base to say hello. BUT, the devs Shatojon and Evax livestreamed a new work in progress update teaser with co-op corruptron combat and base building 3 days ago on 05,13,2016. I can't wait until they release it. I will update this review with my thoughts after I have explored the update, but my first impressions from seeing the livestream are very positive. A co-op bricktron combat alongside co-op base building is exactly what I wanted from this game.

Overall, I am very pleased with my $20 investment. Some people tend to say that every hour of playtime should considered to be about a dollar, and if you come up short on hours spent playing, then it's a bad investment. I personally don't think that's a very good idea of how you should look at the picture. I see it as this: if the game is fun, then it's a good investment, if the game is bad, it's a bad investment. You'll never know if it's good or bad until you invest. Don't take my opinion as the gospel, nor should you take anyone else's opinion as the gospel, since we all have different opinions. If the game looks fun to you, invest, if you don't want to, don't. Just don't whine and moan when the game isn't perfect even though it says right above the Add to cart" button that the game isn't perfect and that it is still in early access. Don't ♥♥♥♥ on the developers who are making this game for a living for not completing the game quick enough. They're taking their time to make the game as perfect as they want it to be
date: updating it and keeping in contact with the customers. Hell
recommended: the developer Shatojon even added me and sent me a message asking my opinion on the game. Has any AAA game developer gone out of their way to actually talk one on one with a customer before? Did Ubisoft go out of their way to ask their consumers' opinions on Assassin's Creed Unity after it was released broken? Nope. The only thing Ubisoft's CEO has said was that ALL Steam users and all PC users are pirates
hoursPlayed: and that he doesn't give a ♥♥♥♥ if the game is broken for us.  Would you
voteText: the consumer
helpfulPercent: really rather have a broken game on release and a CEO of the company you're buying the content from telling you to get bent because he's an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥
votesHelpful: than a game functional in early access and a group of devs who really bust their asses with a game they want people to enjoy? Seriously?"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll keep it short and sweet;  this game makes the DayZ standalone look flawless. I bought it a few days after it was released since I have always enjoyed games involving building and management. It was poorly optimized then too, but I looked past it at first as it was early access. Knowing what I know now I would've requested a refund for my $22 and ran.

Pros:

Really cool concept.
Unique graphical style.
Had tons of potential.

Cons:

The developers gave up on it, if they ever intended to finish it to begin with
Every patch has somehow managed to make the game run worse.
AI is glitchy at best, inoperative at worst.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Holy cow this game has burned me so hard over the years. My first and last Kickstarted project, because of this steaming pile right here.

It has a lot of potential, I'll give it that. It enchanted me on first glance. It kept me hopeful as the devs failed over and over to make meaningful updates, either written or coded. Not anymore.

Boring, buggy, slow, aimless, shallow. That's what we've gotten from 2 years of development. Nary a vision in sight for its future, either. It's sad.

Potential is all the game has, and while I'd love to be proven wrong, I'd bet my Library on it never living up to it. Even half to it. The devs just don't have the passion, vision, or experience needed.

So yeah, pass. Please, for your own sake, pass. Ignore the cool screenshots and videos.

EDIT: Though all of my initial points still stand for the game and studio as it is in the present, this post:

http://www.reddit.com/r/CastleStory/comments/2445q8/when_was_the_last_time_we_actually_had_an_update/ch5hwgu

has been brought to my attention. If they can deliver on the things listed here, then by all means, it will get my glowing recommendation. Until then, pass.

Early Access Review

Okay, it's a good concept, there are many a good idea behind this game. Sincerely, i like the concept.

The problem is the team making this game. They've proven their incompetence more than once.
It will take a very long time to finish, Updates are minimal and have stopped anyway in november, due to refactoring of the game (i.e. they blundered to start with, at least conceptually)

Perhaps when it is actually finished it migth be worth buying. But that will be in half a dozen years at best.
Until that point, or until they start organizing themselves, don't buy, don't support, it's a waste of time and money.

To start, I was one of the original backers of this game on the kickstarter years ago, probably one of the first few hundred, and put a good amount of money into it. Not just saying that to be a hipster about it, but I’ve had many ups and downs with this game, some updates were disappointing, no progress in updating, taking forever to implement feature that made this game worth what I paid for, and at one point I completely forgot it existed for many months.

But after years of waiting, the game is at a point where I can honestly say it’s worth every penny you pay for. It’s still early access, but the devs started to deliver what they promised with the kickstarter. This game has loads of potential, and a lot to offer. Frequent dev updates are keeping people up to date, and I thoroughly enjoy the game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Two years this has been released on early access and it has yet to actullay get finished, reasonably playable or functional. It's a game with a great idea behind it. I love the thought of building a castle and defending it. The issues I have are how this has been executed and the lack of care by the dev team. I've watched this played and I've played it. It doesn't take more than an hour or two to realize that it has some big flaws that need fixing.

Once of the biggest issues I've found is that archers, whom you want on towers to get the best shot angle, will randomly decide to run off your tower, killing themselves instantly. This is very frustrating as even the infrantry units will run up a ram to the top of a wall and dive off to their deaths.

There are lots of other issues like the controls menu not being properly completed, it still shows the control defined names in the code. The graphics options are bad, even for a Unity game, there can be so many more choices on how to change the graphics.

Ideas on how to do basically anything is non-existant. There is a tutorial yes, extremely basic, but it works. It doesn't tell you how to do other tasks like removing blocks, removing tasks or the like.

Overall, this is a great idea, just very very very poorly executed. You might get an hour or two of fun out of it. If you are willing to stick with it, deal with the stupid issues that should be fixed, and make it work, then you can get a few more hours out of it.

BTW, Multiplayer is non-existant, so that's a big lie there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The idea is good, but it becomes vitually implayable after about an hour due to excessive lag. This could be forgiven if the archer AI at least was capable of selecting targets they could actually fire at, as opposed to trying to shoot through walls, friendlies, etc. And even if those issues are not at play, they will stand idle when the nearest enemy is standing below them at the wall, where, remarkably enough, actually dont attempt to shoot through the wall. Nor will they attempt to shoot at an enemy a little further away. They will simply stand and wait for their inevitable demise. Alas their fire cant even be micromanaged due to lag.
So at this point you figure, well what the hell, lets toss in the infantry to kill em. After 4-5 lag-killed attempts to drag a selection box around them, you resort to clicking the select all button. Send them in, by clicking at the enemy. The result natually being that most of them end up atop the wall, rather than go outside and kill the enemy. So, the next time round you click outside the wall and pray to god that their AI routine kicks in before they are slaughtered. They usually stare off a good 5 seconds in the distance before this happens, and a lot can go wrong in this time. And did I mention lag?

It's a shame, I really liked the concept, but there is just no way to make this game work - these sort of issues should have been filtered out a long long time ago in a 3 year development process as they really dont take long to fix. I dont think this game will end up as advertised.

Early Access Review

I'd have to agree with the people not recommending. The game only seems to update when there's a sale. Great PR scheme, but just a warning now to everyone.

-Actual Review-
There are numerous bugs in the game and the 'tutorial' doesn't actually help (that or the mechanics are so horrible that it is unplayable). reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even though I recommend this game, it's really recommended to a more specific group than just to everyone.

Pros:
- Developers are quite interactive with the community on their youtube page sauropodstudio" where you can ask questions as they stream the game every Friday at 3pm US Central time.
- Bugs are few in number and if reported correctly are taken care of quickly.
- Controls are easy to use for RTS veterans and easy to learn for everyone else.
- Pathfinding
recommended:
is well developed for a building RTS.
- *Personal Taste* The graphical fedelity is pleasing to the eye.
- *Personal Taste* The gameplay is simple so not to have unneeded extras.

Cons:
- The game requires a reasonably powerful computer setup to play on anything but simple graphics.
- The game is run on Unity engine which makes the game choppy when you get into later levels with larger waves of enemies.
- *Personal Taste* Some of the more interesting additions have yet to be added to the game.
- The AI pathing for the enemies can be exploited to make the game trivial.
- *Personal Taste* For the current amount of content
hoursPlayed: the price is a little too high.\n- It has no real tutorial so you'll have to watch videos
voteText:
or look at the wiki for help.
- Development is slow due to their small team.

Recommendation is to RTS fans
helpfulPercent: who cross over with Building fans
votesHelpful: such as minecraft
votesTotal: with those who enjoy an easier simpler form of Dwarf Fortress. Buy only if you really believe that the developers vision of the outcome of the game matches your own and you you don't mind waiting for it to be worked out by there relatively small team.\n"
commentsCount: true

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nCastle Story - Early access score of 4/10 This game got me pumped when I first saw it on YouTube. After following the dev's website and waiting for a release I got my hands on it a couple years ago. I waited to post a proper review but after years of waiting I didn't see much improvements to the game. The game is gonna remain in early access for a while with bugs, frame-rate issues, and a completly boring multiplayer experience. Sandbox is probably the best mode for me as survival starts to lag after wave 7. Waves are really short being 4 minutes, I literally had to edit the config file to up that time to 12 minutes so I can at least build my castle. I'm not able to see my archers attack with some strange engine problems causing me to have 10 FPS. It gets insanely hard out of no where, especially with this recent update (10/27) or whichever update included a huge block monster that can 1-shot any warrior, any archer, or anything in it's way. The only way to win the game is to literally make archers. Warriors get 1-shotted. I understand this game is in early access but nothing has really improved since then. Expect updates to come every month being small changes to the GUIs and monsters, and probably some new blocks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-original review- (2014)

This game looked awesome and I was excited for it. When I got the alpha for this game, I thought I saw something that could be great. And for a while I was ok with the small gitchs, and annoying little bugs in the game.

YOU SHOULD STAY AWAY FROM THIS GAME. The devs will treat you like crap, and blame the community for asking too many questions, the game has been stagnant for over a year. The forums have started seeing posts deleted, and users are getting banned for giving out useful information, and asking real questions respectfully.

-2015 review-

Unfortunately, this game seems to be spinning out of control. The devs have banned anyone asking clear, concise questions regarding the progress. The game was actually more playable two years ago than it is now. They spent a great deal of time refactoring the game, telling us that once this was done, we would start seeing content updates, and real progress. Then, when they claimed the refactoring was done... nothing.. Eventually they abandoned the 'roadmap' and progress lists. They do have a 'bleeding edge' which was being updated fairly frequently for a time, but that too has stopped. Now we have an unplayable game. Instead of fixing the game they had with correct AI, useable UI, Multiplayer, and map editing, they began adding a slew of new 'features', almost none of which actually work.
The game was a great concept. It's simplicity was one of its greatest draws. Now it is an incoherent mess.

TL;DR

The devs constantly delete threads or posts with any negative criticism and the development pace is still ridiculous, their shady behaviours (vote manipulation, shills, bans, etc.) haven't stopped.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

August 2014:
Sick an tired of waiting for updates that never come, you can check out their dev diary from their website, but nothing of substance is ever put down, just more excuses about redo all the code an how that will make it easier to add all the new stuff they plan on adding. Been waiting for 6 months for something solid to drop. Nada. The devs are on a huge break living off the crowdfunding and early access money. Im beginning to wonder if they are ever going to finish. Terrible UI, terrible AI, crap for building blocks, terrible management system. WTF. seriously. It had so much promise when i started last year 2013, now.... its just pathetic. So tired of waiting and checking for something new to come out, and i finally had to drop a bad review to them

Edit: JAN2015

Ok so the devs have started to gain some steam, as in they are starting to push content again. Finally, this isnt to say they havent been working because its obvious if you go to their sauropod site that many dev blogs have been released, however.... i am a netsec engineer so i feel like i have alittle bit of insight (not tons) into what the major problem has been, the original system for the game was too clunky and not stream-line so when they needed to add content it took way too much effort to put it in, so they completely scrapped the old and revamped with a better plug n play system so that it didnt take a ton of time to keep introducing new content. Great news right? Well, kinda sorta yeah maybe.   I was so sick of waiting for content for these guys i actually pushed checking on Castle Story to once every 3 months.   WTF.

It looks like the devs are still working but until this game has more to offer that what was originally produced 18 months ago im not giving a reccommendation. I honestly dont care about what problems theyve overcome, when you load the game its still the same crappy 2 survival maps and who wants to just create castles that just sit there begging for the ramparts to be tested but never do?

So much promise in a game, just have to wait an see if they will ever deliver.

JAN2016....

Last update was Nov.2015.... This game had so much promise.... its dead. Just like the crappy studio that thought it would make its customers happy by uploading content on youtube of the staff playing another game that they arent involved with.. instead of finishing that damn game they started. Maybe ill look back in JAN2017.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

12/28/2014
I tried the new update and noticed quite a few improvements. I wouldn't say it's worth buying yet though.

Update Pros:
- Things feel a little bit more smooth.  The AI didn't seem as bad as when I previously played.
- The explainations and ingame notfications are getting better.
- Seems to be less lag with some speed improvements overall.

Cons:
- Islands are still too small.
- AI needs work still.  Seems to be 1 out of 5 times you interact with a Brickton they will stop responding entirely. This leads to a bit of an issue considering some of your Bricktons are archers/warriors. I've lost my base a few times due to this bug.
- Saving is hit or miss.  Sometimes saved games work perfectly... most times Bricktons go missing or it crashes on load.
- Clicking on workers has become challenging. It isn't as nice to right click and drag to select multiple workers now.

All statements in previous review still apply.

----
6/28/2014

I've had this game for quite a few months now and I'm still excited about what it could become.

With that said...  the game isn't close to being finished and there are quite a few baffling design decisions that have been made.

- Why islands?
The small terrain causes incredible frustration while trying to do the most basic things. The islands themselves aren't necessarily the problem but it's how the game can't handle them. The AI is incredibly buggy and stops responding or gets confused on the narrow strips of land. Also, the majority of trees harvested end up flying off the map.

- Additional Content
Why continue to add other content (multi-player?!? etc) on top of a not-solid base game?

Please don't continue to build ontop of a game that needs some serious overhauls in level design, AI design, general gameplay, and in-game priorities.

With all that being said, I hope they turn it around and figure it out. Every once and awhile I'll play it for an hour or so.

Early Access Review

I don't recommend this game, because I bought it half a year ago and I don't see any improvement in the game.
The workers don't move for no reason at some point at the game (sometimes it's from the beginning of the game, sometimes after half an hour). For me it is unplayable and I don't feel in the mood to play it again. I know that it is an alpha, but as I said I didn't see any improvement in the game yet.

Maybe I play it again, when it is in beta stage.
All in all I like the setting of the little yellow buddies and the idea to controll them to build and defend your castle.
I still have my expections in the game and hope that it will get better...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT: After A bit of further testing almost 9 months after I last touched the game, it looks like things have gotten even worse. Granted, some new maps and features have been added, like Iron, but now your brisktrons will randomly path themselves off the map, committing suicide in the name of hauling lumber. I've also encounterd an issue where the game freezes for seceral seconds, and then all of your bricktrons are all stuck falling, unable to move or do anything else, leabing you no ther option than to quit and star over, or reload from a save file. :END EDIT


I purchased this game on EA about 6 months ago after seeing several videos of gameplay. It looked promising. I was excited for a more realistic base builder so to speak. I didnt expect the game to be too fleshed out yet, since that's what early access is. Having played several hours, and feeling like the game had great potential, I put the game down to come back after the devs had ahd a few months to work on it.

Queue last week. I booted up the game, started a new game, and began building the exact same castle on the exact same map I had before. As the first wave of baddies approached, I noticed that they ran around willy-nilly, and just seemed to punch at anything. not particularly impressed, I continued.

About 10 minutes later, it became evident that some work had been done to the AI engine since last I played. Except it seems that the work had been to delete half the brains of all the entities in the game. The workers would regularly all attempt to place the same block, take the same narrow path when there were a multitude of options, and regularly block each other in to the point where 5 of them were all stuck in one spot, all trying to get past each other, but to no avail. I even noticed the knights swinging their swords the WRONG WAY when in combat. I real flop if you ask me.

All in all, the game looks promising, but it appears that the dev studio is working by the old creedence One step forward

First of all, the game's really early release, so I didn't expect much. But I got even less that that, in my opinion. While there is a ton of potential, and I'm really looking forward to what the game COULD be, right now it's sorely lacking in quite a few areas.

The first, and by far the biggest and worst, area is the controls. Less than half of the controls actually feel streamlined and as if they should work. All the rest are clunky, hard to remember, and completely out of left field. I mean, hold space and drag your middle mous click to move your camera? What? And the controls can't be changed individually according to task. You can just change what keystrokes/clicks the game recognizes. So, for example, you can't change the turn blueprint" key

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Feelings of disillusioned loomed 6 months ago, but with a recent update proudly touting the return of the pause function and that objects that fall into the abyss are now removed from the world instead of indefinitely floating in space, it became clear this game would never deliver.  Did the people that wrote the seed leave/die, or is Sauropod simply out of their depth in taking on this sizable AI feat?  There's been no appreciable improvement in minion behavior-- which is crucial to this game -- for a year.  Even things that seem like obvious bug squashes loom.  They still kick the logs they just harvested off the edge of the world.  They still go idle randomly.  They still build themselves into a corner.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really want to like this game, but the most important thing standing in my way is the interface.

I don't fancy playing in creative, so my view is from the survival aspect. In survival you have to quickly start building a castle and defend it against wave after wave of ever-increasing numbers of attackers. The key word here is quickly.

There is no pause, so you cannot stop and plan your castle out and then set your people to work, so you are instantly stressed. This could be fine if the interface otherwise supported speedy planning and building, but it does not.

The game seems very much built for consoles (or at least using a controller) because it just about only uses the mouse totally disregarding the keyboard for anything but camera navigation. In a game with so many things to build, getting even the simplest things made is a pain.

In order to build anything you have to first click the right mouse button and hold it for about 1 second. Then choose build mode. Then right click and hold for about a second again to get a radial menu where you then select the category of things you want to build and then you can finally select the specific item you want. So even building the simplest little storage box quickly takes 3-4 seconds. If you then want to switch items you want to build, you have to again hold the mouse and go through the waiting once more. In a game where you have 10 minutes before the first wave of attackers and ever less time before the next attacks spending 3-4 seconds per item you want to place into the world will make you frustrated beyond compare.

Again, I love the style and the idea, but the interface just kills it.

It seems like the designers like a sleek no on-screen menu interface so much they are willing to sacrifice a lot to get it. I urge them to reconsider seeing as any amount of waiting for menus in a no-pause survival game is infuriating and stressfull and is bad game design. Please, dear designers, consider adding a toolbar at the bottom and more use of the keyboard so the all the waiting for menus goes away, or at least add a pause function. A pause function would not remove the irritating wait time, but it would remove the infuriating stressfulness.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's been a long time since I knew this game had potential, but Sauropod encountered problem in the first steps of the development. After 200h ingame, I stoped. I came back yesterday, and I have to say: this potential clearly became reality with the last patchs.

There are 4 main modes (for the moment):
-Peace mode: build your own castle (tunnel and bridge) and expand it to a whole map in peace mode. Perfect to practice!!
-Survival mode: try to survive as long as possible to the enemies waves. You'll have to smartly build your castle and defend it with your archers, knights, catapults and traps. (dificulties: easy, normal, hard)
-Conquest mode: build multiple structure and try to expand your kingdom to capture enemie's base without being attacked in your main castle. (dificulties: easy, normal, hard)
-Coop peace mode: build with your friends!

There is also a map editor and a lot of new content upcoming.


Don't care about these old review pointing the bad optimisation, or saying this game is dead. They are wrong, castle story is alive, improving and WAITING FOR YOU SOLDIER! If you like strategic/construction/war game , this one is definitely for you!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A nice concept. Not really a game in there at least yet. What is disgusting is the implementation. They collected quite some money on kickstarter. Either they are incompetent or bordering criminal - but development speed is crawling. The recent .50 update for example is still not usable. This is years after original planned development. Now release date is early 2016.... amazing. With the current speed demonstrated in the last 2 years I would rather think it is 2026 or later.

Hope is there - also that they find a game in the concept, because right now there is no real game in it. But past performance is an indicator of future performance, so it will not release in any really usable way in 2016.

It is a fun little sandbox with some enemies coming in game mode. It sadly is unstable and has a horrific performance.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I thought this game was going to be great.. i really did. but there are way too many bugs for me to enjoy it. i know it is in beta so there should be bugs but there are too many game-breaking bugs. i only get to actually play the game about 25% of the time. When i click play, 75% of the time nothing shows up yet it says im playing it. this has happens way too often.
Also, it crashes. It crashes a lot. So i need to save my game every five minutes so i dont lose progress when it crashes. But, after about four crashes in one setting, it gets better, but i still save a lot to be safe.
Lastly, the A.I is almost completely broken. At first they work well for about four waves besides when half of the bricktrons stand in place when i call them back to the castle when the corrupted are coming. After about wave four, the builders dont build, and when i click on them to move somewhere they stand still. Even the corrupted are buggy. half of the time, they go straight past the castle and stand on the edge of the island and i need to send my warriors after them to get the loud, but good, music to stop. And half the time the warriors just stand in place as thcorrupted raid my castle and kill all of my bricktrons.
Ok, that was a lot of hate. I do like this game when it works, but dont think you should buy it for the $20.00 price until its fixed. This game can be good, but needs a lot more work and i think you should wait until its out of beta or at least a bit more fixed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is going to be used as a textbook example of why you should never buy an early access game.  These guys sold a lot of copies of an exercise turned tech demo.  If I were in their boots, I'd be done.  Why make a game when you cut your losses and run... and by losses, I mean a whole lot of cash up front with absolutely zero accountability to finish the game.

Yes, early access means it's not done... and that's the problem with early access; It never has to be done to be sold. NEVER!

I wish I was back in school where I would make little game" concepts.  A few exercised examples and you pass.  Never had to worry about making it a full functioning game... that would have taken the entire semester if not longer to finish. ...but if I polished it just enough to put on kickstarter... cha-ching!  A few days or months of work for a pay out equivalent to the entire gaming dev life-cycle.  From a purely financial point of view
date: the payout from work is done."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr: This game is still in Alpha stage, with lots of gamebreaking bugs, it has appeared very clear the devs aren't competent enough to finish it.  It has yet to be demonstrated that they are actually still working on it. I highly recommend against buying it.

Sauropod studio has made close to no progress on their sole project in the last 2 years, despite having received an ample amount of money through crowdfunding (kickstarter then Steam early access).

They are not struggling to live and work on the game at the same, they simply are incompetent. Moreover, their general attitude toward criticism is childish at best, they do not hesitate to censor any comment if they can.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've abandoned this game for 3 years until recently, and i decided to try it out again, see what's changed. Not THAT much has changed, but there are noticeable differences. I abandoned this due to the AI at the time, but now the AI is actually competent and the game is playable now. The game might be slow paced as they have to mine rocks in order to build bricks, but it is quite fun building. There is quite a variety of blocks to choose from, from normal 2x1 to rounded ones and archways. Stairs too. 3 years ago the edit mode (mode to place blocks) was extremely difficult to use and it just wasnt fun to build. But now they've refined it and it is quick and easy to select and place blocks. No snapping in the wrong places anymore. There also are other modes where you get attacked by rock monsters and you have to defend yourself by placing down archers and catapults, which is fun. I mostly like sandbox though. There also is multiplayer, but i havent tried it yet. But from what i've heard, multiplayer is stable. So the end verdict? This game might not be perfect, but it sure is shaping up.

7.8-10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe first few hours of Castle Story seemed to scratch a castle-building itch I had been having. Seeing as this is an Early Access title, I was more than willing to endure the countless AI bugs that left my Bricktrons doing absolutely nothing and repeatedly ignoring my commands. I was determined to build and epic, sprawling citadel to defend against the oncoming waves of enemies. Sadly, it wasn't long before defending against the repetetive waves of identical, easily dispatched foes lost its charm. I could not fault Castle Story for its lack of content, it IS and Early Access game. So, I waited. A check of their website said they were re-factoring" their code. This was indeed a lengthy process and five or so months later

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Update for v0.6

Game remains unplayable. Bugs that have persisted for 4 years now have not been addressed and show no sign that the dev team have the ability to resolve them and bring this game to a state where it will be a playable *game*

Since purchasing this game I have discovered that the foundering team were two graphics designers at university. So far it seems they haven't tauight themselves to program in any meaningful way, and all the programmers they hire seem to swiftly quit.

It sadens me to discover that instead of working hard on fixing real problems with their game, they have spent a great deal of time and resouces adding cosmetic (useless)  enhancements for christmas and halloween, as well as amassing many fake reviews and other PR spin to try to fool others into donating more of their hard earnt dollars to their existing holiday fund that was around $700,000 from kickstarter, and a mininum of $300,000 from steam (yes, thats around $1 million dollars)

Grade A scammers. You have been warned.

SAVE YOUR MONEY
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

Every wonder why this game has so many negative reviews but the forums are overwhelmingly positive?

That's because this games developers activly delete negative forum posts and ban those post's authors in an effort to hide the fact that this game has not recieved any significant update with ingame improvements in over 3 years.

Every year prior to the Christmas, for 3 years running now, Sauropod have released a series of fake updates to Castle Story to create the illusion of activity in hopes of cashing in on the Christmas season sales.

You don't hear about it on the forums because everyone who comments about it gets swifly banned.

Save your money, avoid this game at all costs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I strongly recommend this game if you like building games.

In this game you begin with a few workers and start extracting ressources to build the castle of your dream, or anything that you dream of, hire more workers or soldiers. You place the blueprints and they will build it. There is a variety of ressources, stones and wood blocks and structures such as columns, door, catapult, lights and more.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=662639776
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=639994359
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=435746516

There is also a fighting part to the game, if you play invasion or conquest mode, you have to defend against hordes of evil creatures called corruptrons.

I have this game since a 2 or 3 years and development of the game was continuous, features are added regularly, and the devs are close to the community, they listen and reply to feedbacks and suggestions.

The is a multiplayer mode, which is basic at the moment but will get optimised soon according to dev team.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Castle Story is my current favorite steam game.
You can create castles and defend your crystal from the corruptrons.
You can order your bricktrons to work for you to build your castle.
It's pretty much epic.

Okay let's get serious...
You start out in the woods with a couple of little bricktrons.
You have to make them collect resources to build a castle around your crystal.
If the corruptrons get to your crystal and destroy it, It's game over.
Of course there is free play whitch is just building but without corruptrons.
So yeah that's mainly what the game is, Think of it this way, If you like empires you'll like castle story.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL:DR
Dev saw I was not happy, then he helped me step by step and now I'm enjoying the game a lot more.
It means a lot to me when the Devs interact with the players and take the time to help out.

I couldnt for the life of me figure out how to create a stockpile, needed to refine and store resources for building, so I pretty much couldnt do anything and the Tutorial was not helpful with this task. Basically all the power in this game comes from holding down the RIGHT mouse button and depending on what or where you are holding the cursor, the options will change. SOMEHOW i missed this but all is well now.

I tried playing this game a few times over the years and struggled with the tutorial and wasnt able to figure out basic game mechanics. Tried it again today hoping to see that it had changed because I was always keen to see where this game would go, but alas. I was stuck in the same rut as previously. I went and wrote a review explaining the faults I saw and decided I'd be back in a few more months to see what has changed.
Well, one of the Devs went saw the review, added me and offered to help, he politely explained step by step what I had missed and now finally I am able to play!

The tools (once you've figured them out) are simple and the options limitless as to what you can build.
Really stoked to have been helped by the Devs and its made all the difference with my attitude towards the game, go sell some of your unused AWP skins and pick this game up, these fat little yellow men are way cuter than your 'worm god stat track' AWP anyway.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very promising idea. Very poor execution.

The UI tries to be minimalistic and fresh, but comes off as clunky and unintuitive. Spending most of my time trying to remember how to get it to do what I want is usually a bad sign. Anything you want to do is buried below at least two or three levels of menus. That's a big no-no for anyone who knows how to do a UI.

The performance for a game like this minimal really shouldn't be bad, but it bogs down after only a few minutes. That makes it even more difficult to play.

Even worse, the AI is frustratingly dumb. In a game like this, I would've fixed and polished that first, even if the UI wasn't ready. The little workers spend way too much time in a stupor when time is often of the essence. When they do work, it's often not very efficient. They can build themselves and others into a corner. Stockpiles can fill up with worthless junk while the vaulables sit untouched nearby. Often they fill up the nearest stockpile instead of the most full, giving you a bunch of half-full and unusable piles. One missed or misplaced block (or even one closed door) can render an entire castle useless.

Just needs way more polish and actual listening to feedback. With the updates coming every few months and not really seeming to do much, I wouldn't hold out much hope. Avoid this and go buy something fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I honestly think that this is the worst game I have ever played. Just listing the flaws would take several pages.
But here are some:
- Worst interface ever. The interface is SO bad that it kinda remind of old Dos games. It is like the designers have never played a game in their life. For example, it takes 6 clicks to load a game.
- Nonexistent AI. Workers will cross your city to pick up a material, while there was the same material right where he was.
- Workers freeze regularly. It often takes up to 12 seconds for a worker to start executing an order.
- I think it's the first time I turn my speakers off in a game. Not only is the music and FX bad, but the Options don't work (as most of the things in the game) so even set at 0% the music still plays.
- Graphics are bad.
- TONS of bugs.

However, the worst thing is that the game has absolutely nothing good or slightly original to it. It's basically Warcraft I horribly executed by a talentless team.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

** Update: I have changed my below review to negative because it's been almost a year since I posted it and there still haven't been any actual updates and nothing has changed on the development blog. I was one of the 27,060 Kickstarter backers and had high hopes. These guys basically made $702,516 to make a cool promo video.  Now they just blog about playing other games and going to gaming conventions.  I hope that another developer takes some of the cool ideas these guys came up with and actually make a playable game.

Sauropod Studio came up with one of the coolest ideas for a game that I have ever seen.  It’s kind of a cross between building with Legos , Minecraft,  and an RTS game like Age of Empires.   This game was funded on Kickstarter in the summer of 2012 which is about a year and a half ago from when I’m posting this review.  The game is fun to play, but can actually be annoying and stressful.  You have to keep in mind that this is a prerelease so there is no guarantee that it will even run on your computer at all.  That being said here are some of the issues that you will run into if you end up purchasing version 0.1.2.20dc. You have to save the game all the time just in case something breaks and you need to revert to the previous save.  The pace of doing anything is extremely slow.  It has a lot of quarks that make everything difficult unless you want to spend the time to figure out workarounds for the bugs.  E.g. you have to Shift-Right Click to move the workers all the time so that they drop whatever they’re doing and do what you are trying to make them do. You have to Right Click on Barrels and add the types of materials they can take otherwise the workers stop mining. The little bricktron workers get stuck anytime anything gets in the way because the AI and path finding doesn’t work yet.  The Camera, UI, and the controls are also just really unintuitive and not user friendly.  I really wish the developers would listen to the fans and focus on making the sandbox fun and playable for everyone without spending development time on trying to implement new content and new features.  There is also no development time-line or expected finish date so it could be years before this is a full game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I originally purchased this game, like many others, as soon as it was available. The idea was simple: I liked the game, and wanted to see it improve. The problem came when no improvements were made.

In two years they've fixed one or two major bugs, optimized the engine slightly, added the ability to save - but that's the extent of it. With the money they've collected, and the amount of people working on the game, this result (or lack thereof) is disasterous.

This kind of slow, $#@%ty work might be acceptable in the public sector, but in the private sector there's accountability, and there's backlash when you take people's money and don't make good on your end of the deal. Simply put, Sauropod is yet another dishonest group of people taking advantage of the early-access / crowd funding systems. Don't give them your money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I, like many, originally backed this game on Kickstarter. The very nature of kickstarter is like most other investments, where the backers are absorbing all the risk on a promise of some sort of return, be it financial or in this case, a game. Of the various things I've backed on Kickstarter, this is the only one I truly regret.

Why?

Anything that I say has already been said in other reviews. The progress in development has been incredibly, painfully slow. Games that were pitched/came out after Castle Story have rapidly over taken it in every way. Commonly cited examples are Space Engineers and Prison Architect.

Even if you could objectively state that development progress isn't slow, consumer psychology is a powerful thing. Why are goods sold for £0.99 instead of £1.00? We perceive it to be far cheaper, when the reality isn't such. If people believe development progress to be slow, then it's slow unless you definitively prove otherwise.

So if I agree with the other reviews, why am I coming out of the woodwork?

It's the antagonistic nature with which this studio engages with the player base. There will always be people who are unhappy, it's the very nature of exchanging money for goods/services. However, beneath all the anger and poorly chosen words are legitimate concerns and questions that go unanswered, or worse still, answered with equal levels of vitriol and abrasion. Think of the silent observers, like I used to be, quietly asking the same questions? Some of the exchanges between the community and the developers of this game are legitimately scary. Reading the castle story subreddit was an eye opener.

In conclusion, it wasn't a mistake to back this game originally. With the information I had and the strength of their pitch, I was happy to invest and I would do it again. However with all the information available to all of us today, my opinion is that investing would be a mistake. All I can hope is that it would stop them treating the people that invested in their ideas, which by extension means investing in them as people and their future, with such contempt.

Early Access Review

I've followed this game from the kickstarter. I didn't participate in the kickstarter, but i did buy it from Humble store over a year ago. There hasn't been any real progress in the development all this time. Some minor fixes here and there but significant core parts are STILL missing like pause function.
The game doesn't tell you if your workers cannot complete a job. I've done my part and tried kindly give hints about missing things that i find important but i fail to see that it has had any effect at all. There are dozens of bug reports about same bugs but they rarely are fixed in a timely manner. Tutorial was added due to massive request from community but it is so basic that i fail to see why it took so many months before it was implemented. Many community made basic game guides were made literally in days after this game was released in Steam Early Access.
I cannot recommend this game to anyone. It is still a prototype. I do still hope that this will be a good game some day but i am losing faith in Sauropod Studio. 100th blog is what brought me to write this review. Roadmap for the development was in their 50th blog over a year ago but it still hasn't been finished. They also introduced a support web page almost a year ago but it doesn't contain any bugs reported so it is basically useless.
Still i wish luck for Sauropod Studio and hope that they will pick up the pace with the game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rather cute game, which I wasted a few hours on.
Now as a disclamer, I do realise that this is an early access game, but as it stands, it is barely playable. At this point the core game should be up and working, with a few minor bugs here and there. (i.e. No major game breaking bugs.)

Firstly, I was constantly fighting with the pathfinding/AI of the bricktons (Workers).
Half the time they would either get clogged, run on the spot, refuse to be assigned to an objective, become unselectable, sometimes wait 5-10+ secconds to figure out a simple path from A to B, take the longest and most inefficient route and in general; they do not do what I want when I want it. Almost NEVER.

You have the choice between two combat units: Archer (Ranged) and Soldier (Melee)
The Soldier being useless, as 99% of the time will run past the enemy he's chasing.
So you have to basically rely on archers. Except they're prone to shooting each other in the back, and trying to shoot through your resource stashes, destroying them with a single arrow.
There are also catapaults, Which i couldn't figure out how to work (Couldn't seem to assign any tasks to them or drop stuff on them)

The level design looks cool, but functionally is an absolute pain to deal with.
I lost countless resources (Trees and stone) into the abyss thanks to them (especially the trees) being next to the edge and 95% of the time, the physics would tip towards the edge instead of inwards. (And you have no control over how they fall.)

There is also no variety in the enemy's you face. Only the one zerg rush type.

The save system is also buggy, I saved my first game (After about 1-2 hours of play) and then immedietly reloaded it. (There was a builder looping a falling sound, who was stuck in a mine.) It wouldn't load, so I lost that save.

If the other reviews are anything to go by (And the release date of Sept 2013) It doesn't seem like any of these problems will be fixed anytime soon. There have been patches recently, but there are still an absolutly massive number of issues.

This is interesting concept, one that I liked the look of, but has been very poorly executed. A majority of it seems to be implemented with Unity's stock-standard features, And it suffers for it.

I wouldn't buy it again.

TL;DR: Cute but terribly broken game with the outlook of few to no useful updates in the future. Go elsewhere.

Early Access Review

(TL;DR at bottom)

I was looking at this game when it first came out on kickstarter - and bought game when it came out on steam because I thought it had such a great potential. It still does, believe me! Tho.. I've played it a bit back and fourth and have seen a couple of 200MB and 300MB updates but has there been any changes? Sadly, not that I've seen.

The gameplay hasn't changed and the workers bugs out all the time and there's nothing you can do to prevent it. How are we supposed to test a game and give feedback when we can't even play the game properly?

In multiplayer it's near impossible for someone else to connect to your server and when they manage to do so you can't even see what they are building and one of you randomly win because of god knows what.

I had big hopes for this game but as of now I do not recommend this game to anyone.

TL;DR: Do not buy this game, it might seem like the devs are updating the game but they aren't. There are tons of gamebreaking bugs that hasn't been fixed in nearly a year.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game was an intriguing prototype, but that's all it is and ever was at this point, it's *barely* an 'Alpha', more of a playable demo. It has seen NO updates at all in well over a year apart from changing alternating between some holiday themed skins for a couple of different items and the dev's themselves go out of their way to avoid/ignore their community.

I highly suggest doing the same to this game.

I can't say for sure if this was a scam or not. If it was; the damage is pretty much done - if it wasn't, this team has shown NO progress to speak of for an untenable amount of time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sorry, but this game is nowhere near being worth the price it is selling for in it's current state.  Early Access is no excuse.  The interface is horrible, the AI for the bricktrons is atrocious.  I tried survival mode and found the hardest part was not actually defending against the waves of baddies, but keeping my Bricktrons on track building my defenses.  The worst part was they would just straight up stop and do nothing, when this happens you have to try and figure out what part of your structure they don't like and fix it.  Maybe you have a brick too high in one place, maybe the ground is uneven in another, good luck figuring it out, because there's no in game way to notify you when there's a construction problem.

Bottom line is, this game has a lot of potential, and it could possibly be really good, but right it's just garbage for the current $20 (non sale) pricetag.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Side note thing: I think this game has a really good idea. I think the game itself is amazing too. I have no idea why people hate this. Every problem they said they had has never happened to me. I do think $20 for this game might be a little too much though. I think it would do better if it was atleast maybe $10-$15? I wont stop supporting these devs (No matter how much hate they get) UNLESS, this game utterly fails. Then id have no reason to support this game if it utterly fails.
Anyway.
Castle Story is a Resource Management,Survivalish game. You build castles and protect your castle along with a crystal that can summon warriors, archers, and workers. There are 2 different modes right now (Sandbox, and Survival) There is also a tutorial you can take too. Which I would reccomend.
Pros: +Great idea
+Characters move just fine for me
+Nice music
Cons: -A bit buggy with building (It is Early Access)
-Devs are a bit slow (but I dont mind)
Thats all I have to say for now, This is all my opinion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A few years ago, they were deleting topics that disagreed with them from the forums, and development looked dead. I recently took a look to see if it had gotten anywhere, and it's really taken off. There's weekly developer livestreams, great interaction with players, and new content, bug fixes and optimizations rolling in regularly.

I love the freedom you have to mess around with the world, to create or change chokepoints as it fits your strategy. On the side of things to improve, to me, it feels a bit too fast paced as I like to think things through well and make sure everything's 100% right. And the game doesn't really like the scale I try to make things in.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The ability to let the player be creative in the making of forts and castles is a very important feature in a game like this... and it is done well here.

I bought Castle Story a while ago (before many of the current feature were implimented) and had fun creating catles and defending them. A couple months ago I rediscovered Castle Story and had a blast with the new features like Conquest Mode.

While playing the game I didn't really encounter any bugs or glitches with the game.

Pros:
-Allows Creativity
-Interesting setting (on floating islands in a sort of isolated place)
-Different features allow for more types of play style.
-Challenging yet exciting

Cons (some might just be my computers fault):
-while building castles I find it difficult to build or fix things on the inside of the structure
-when I have been playing for a bit and the waves in Invasion Mode start to get more difficult I find that I need more        Bricktrons, but my gameplay gets a bit choppy when I get to around 7-8 Bricktrons. When I get to 10 or more Bricktrons my computer just can't handle it and will either crach or become very difficult to play.
-when I put my archers up on the walls they will do fine unless I choose to fight with my swordsmen too. Then I have to micro-manage them to make sure they don't hit friendly troops.

Overall: Castle Story is a good game and is worth the money. If I had to give it a rating it would be 8/10 (my rating will probably be higher when the game has been completed) still though if you have the creativity and a computer that can run the game well, then for you it could be way better than you might think.



As a little note for the end of my review I would like to be the selfish player who puts out a few ideas that I have no right to demand for but would still like to see.    :)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1) It would interesting to see a way to play as the Corruptrons either in singleplayer or multiplayer.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
2) A way to save creations would save a lot of time as well as giving the players a way to hurry past the parts of the game  he/she may find tedious.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
3) In Sandbox mode it is super fun to just go nuts and build a bunch of stuff but it would be interesting to see how such creations would fair in Invasion Mode, but it can be boring to have to rebuild them block by block (especially if they are large creations). So a way to put Corruptrons in Sandbox Mode would be fun and allow players to test their creations before starting an Invasion Mode playthrough.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4) It would be fun to be able to rename the Bricktrons to names that are more personal or funny.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Thats my thoughts on Castle Story. I look forward to seeing how the game developes.
I hope this review has been helpful. Thank You for reading it.

-Mr.Duck

P.S.: I love the Castle Story website.

Fun game.  The bricktrons are like your own army of minecraft steves.  Sandbox mode can give you hours of fun, especially if you like building elaborate castles.  Invasion and conquest allow you to test your structural designs against waves of enemies and really feel like you've build a castle and not a pointless block structure.

The game is still developing, and releases have made the game progressivly better.

The only downside is that playing multiplayer requires some networking knowledge.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I first purchased this game a few years back.  I tried it a few times, and while i found it fun, i found issues with it, and decided to wait a while longer before i really gave it a fair shake.

Cut to recently, when i again decided to dive back into Castle Story, and I am glad i did!

The game is fun!!!

I was amazed at how different the Castle Story of today looks and plays over what i initially experienced.  I've been playing it for a while now, and i have yet to encounter any AI issues, framerate issues, or honestly, ANY bugs of any kind.

Give this game a try... the road has been slow going, but i think it was worth the wait!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the first time I have written a review so im going to just start out by talking about the game then I will get into a more pro/con format later in.

I played castle story back when it was just out of the prototype stage and there were many problems. two of the biggest problems were the path finding of the units and the camera's controls, everything else was injoyable. I have taken over 2 year break from this game. After the break I have come back to islands (maps) that are 10x as big as the first island"
date: two new game modes conquest (capture the point) and invasion (wave survival)
recommended: a normal camera control system and enemys that you have to defend against. To add on to all that devs are getting ready to launch a multiplayer update where we can share control with friends or battle against one another (but as thats not in yet I will keep that out of my mind for the rest of the review). The game mode conquest is not very injoyable to me but the invasion mode is very challenging but fun so I'm going to focus on invasion. In invasion you start out with a few workers
hoursPlayed: a knight
voteText: an archer and your crystal (homebase) so you stright away get to work setting jobs and delgating how many workers you want doing diffrent jobs such as chopping trees for wood
helpfulPercent: working the iron mines
votesHelpful:
working in your querry for stone to make bricks or building your stronghold. Now building is a little unique you have to build your structures one brick at a time (you can click and drag so its not tedious) which means you can end up with a stronghold that can take multiple hits of explosive barrels or one. You can make you stronghold tall or wide its up to you but you do have to make sure you put supports under your structures so that your building doesn't collapse on its self. So I would say that castle story is a game that has seen a lot of growth and is at a stat were its fun to play.

Some pros and cons:

Pros:very good looking
easy to build structures
challenging to balance jobs
varying sizes of maps
terrain deformation/reformation
you can build any size or shape structure
stress system
camera is not unusable like early releases
devs are always releasing updates
Cons:takes large amounts of time to complete structres
big map has some framerate issues
not all game modes on every map
bugs where enemys dont charge your base
when builting unless you have two wide paths there may be some pathing issues
minor lighting bugs
If you have the money to spare I think castle story is a game you should pick up."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Another wave of black clay men are quickly advancing towards the southern walls of my Castle. On the wall stands a group of my yellow clay men workers, having just finished a big renovation project after the wall was almost destroyed in a previous assault. They stand no chance of holding the wall so I scroll over to my group of warriors, currently mopping up the few remaining hostiles who just tried to destroy my western walls. I order most of my warriors and archer to rush to southern walls, If I am lucky they will make it there before the attackers and I will be able to hold my castle, if not they will swam into my courtyard, kill my workers and surround my warriors.

I am confident that my warriors will be able to hold my newly completed and fortified walls so instead I have a look at my recently attacked western side. There is small gap in the wall caused by the now dead attackers that I need to get repaired before any additional hostiles decide to follow up on their friends previous assault so I have my workers evacuate the soon to be attacked southern walls and send them to fix the bretch. Neither the workers or the warriors arrive. The warriors and the workers run into each others, stopping for what looks like a long and pleasant chat as they try to path around one another failing horribly as the attacker make a huge hole in my new wall. All of my yellow clay men gets surrounded slaughtered.

SUMMARY:
Castle Story is a game with what sounds like a great concept but has horrible execution. The two biggest issues are the pathing and UI. The pathing causes your claymen to frequently bump into each others, stopping them in their tracks as they try to find a way around their new found friend despite it being plenty of space on both sides of them. The UI requires you to navigate multiple radial menus just to build a stockpile, it is very clunky and unnecessarily complicated. I would stay away from Castle Story, it has been almost 3 years since the initial early access release and not much has happened since then.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before you buy this, know that there has not been any significant content update for several months. I understand early access means in development, but that would actually require some development on the developers part.

While the game is entertaining for the first few hours, it becomes boring quickly, lacking the ability to do more than just build a castle. The survival mode is moderately entertaining for awhile but in essence, its survive against waves that come at you in a straight line. Its predictable and therefor gets boring easily.

There are several pros and cons, the pros being a unique new type of gameplay compared to other sandbox games, however it has many shortcomings such as lack of building materials and lack of blocks, which severely limits creativity. Making this sandbox game, not worth the money.

Overall I cant recommend a game that is boring and has not progressed in development for months. If things change, I will definately change my review.

Early Access Review

What can i say, a lot of my hours was spent quite early on in this project,  but for the last 9-6 months i have barely looked at the game,  Why?  because its in the same state it was, excluding a pause button when i originally bought it.  Oh yeah forgot about crystals in barrels as well.

Oh well - still can't recommend BUT they do tell us it will be released  early 2016 (so early for me is first 3 months)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

VERSION 0.6.4 REVIEW

===

Pros & Cons
+ Pros +

+ Very good mix of Sandbox, Tower Defence and Strategy that actually works
+ You can build your very own fortress and defend it with an army
+ Totally destructible / modifiable environment
+ Added sandbox mode to build without worry of attacks
+ Simple enough control system allows you to do what you need quickly
+ AI has improved much since past versions and now can do complex tasks without errors
+ Good building system / task system that doesn't make a mess of what is going on and keeps it clean
+ Multiplayer has been improved and now works properly
+ Good variety, for an Early Access, of parts and structures to build

- Cons -

- Camera system could be better
- You still have to dig resources in sandbox mode, instead of having everything unlimited like a proper creative" mode
- Kinda poor variety of units to either build or to face in battle as enemies

===

Personal opinion
Castle Story is surely a game with lots of potential
date: and still has time and quite a long way to be able to fully express the possibilities available to its gameplay. Still
recommended: it has improved a lot since the past versions
hoursPlayed: devs actually listened to the community on what should be done to improve the game
voteText: and did it.\n\nThis mix of Defense
helpfulPercent: RTS and Sandbox can be found in very few other games i know of
votesHelpful: and it's worth to give a try to anyone who likes building his own stuff and/or RTS in general.\n\nIt can really be fun to defend your own castle
votesTotal: underground fortress or whatever you want to build against increasingly difficult enemies
votesFunny: think of it as a Stronghold mixed with Minecraft
commentsCount: pretty epic isn't it?\n\nI will update this review when updates come out
column16:
stay tuned.

===

ACTUAL RATING: 8/10
"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Terrible Developers.

Over the last year they have been working on trying to make a simple voxelbased game work properly.
There has not been a single new content patch and the game is still not working correctly.

This is a basebuilding game where you defend yourself from Evil Rock-People that want to ravage your base at night.
You do this by building and as time goes on you have to build strategical walls and place archers and soldiers inside your base.

There is a multiplayermode that barely works where you can wreck havoc and do as you please to your opponent but as of now there is no co-op feature and setting up a server is hard work for those who just want to jump in and play as there are no dedicated servers.

As it sound it is a faily simple game yet quite hard in the later levels if you play in the survival mode. Though I woud still not recommend this title as it is not going anywhere. On it's own it is quite fun but it is a thing that you would only spend a few couple of hours into and then never touch it again until they add more content and depth to the game.
I've only come back to play it because the first hours was a pain since nothing worked.

Might be worth buying on a 75% sale.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Castle Story is a bad game.

I have waited and waited for patches but none have came. I want a refund but since I live in the Corporate States of America comrade Ridah can have no refunds.

So let me spit down why this game is bad.

The UI/Controls are very poor  and consolized. Its almost painfull to try and play this on PC and as of 1/13/2014 there is only a very very basic game here. Its almost insulting they can get away with selling this on steam or many of these types of early access games. Valve dousn't care, they take the money and so does the dev. Beyond that, theres no one watching over this stuff.

But back to the game, basically the UI is so consolized its confusing and just really awful to use on PC. The AI also have issues where they will occasionally just stop responding, stop working, and nothing can make them go back to work. Even if you did get to build something theres not much to do, its just not fun.

I gave it a chance, its just horrible. Theres only the basic guise of a fun game and beyond that...nothing. I think an EA game would be better honestly, atleast they have to release a full game to fool people to buying it. Its messed up when I can say comparatively to this, that EA games are full" games when half of the content is cut for later DLC releases at a premium overprice."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I found myself interested in this game before it was even available on Steam. I became excited with the concept. On the outside it looks cute and intresting, the Developers promised a Castle building wonderland where you construct and defend you castles from strange night corrupt versions of your builders. This peaked my intrest because it was both simple, yet engaging, not over complicated like a lot of games have become.
Just clean good fun. So when it was available for Early Access I of course bought it. Now it has a lot of work to do, most of the basic concepts are there but a lot still need to be included, and a hell of a lot of work needs to be done on the features that do exist to remove bugs and glitches and other nastys. I know what your thinking, it's Early Access, thats to be expected.
Well... That was a year ago.
Nothing has changed, nothing has been added, sometimes a small bug fix will be released but nothing more. I don't even check for updates anymore. They game developers have taken at least a million dollers for this and yet nothing.
I'm afraid like a lot of early Access games they have taken your money and ran.
This game, and a few others like it have ruined Early Access for me. I no longer intend to buy them because of it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While this game does have a seemingly great concept, it quickly falls short of all expectations.

This game is still in Alpha, and although it is kind of playable, it is still full of bugs and glitches and other problems.
Now this is normally ok because with an alpha comes many updates to quickly fix issues, but the developers behind this game must have missed that memo.

Updates are released quite slowly with very little to show with each one. No new features added in for months, AI pathfinding still playing up, plus many other things have gone for months unfixed which has made it somewhat of an effort to even want to play this game any more.

What could have been a very great game, has not yet delivered. And at the rate of update releases won't be delivered for a long time.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFive-hundred and forty-one days.  541 days.  1 year, 5 months, 23 days.  This is the amount of time to date since the Kickstarter campaign ended. Literally NOTHING has been accomplished.  I understand this is an indie company but after all this time, they don't have a playable product.  Updates are infrequent and frivolous.  Dev logs consist of trivial nonsense.  Sauropod Studios is way over their head. Your combination of few employees and complete lack of knowledge pertaining to anything about making games has quite literally turned Castle Story into the biggest disappointment in indie gaming history. I don't expect Sauropod Studios to ever make another game, ever. You obviously do not have the proper team or experience. Very disappointed.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI wanted to like this game. It was like building in minecraft only you have a small army of AI units to tell what to build. On paper it sounded great but I have massive doubts about the developers ability to refine this game to a playable degree. The .3 patch reverted about a years worth of bug fixes and has nearly broke the game to an unplayable" state. This game is plagued with bugs that will waste hours of your time trying to figure out how to work around it just for the sake of stacking blocks. Their video blogs are just annoying to watch as all they do is talk about what they would like to accomplish while never really hitting these goals. It sounds all great but little to none of it ever gets ironed out. I bought this game over a year ago and have seen little forward advance. The last big patch cranked down the texture quality in order to increase the map size but failed to fix the major problems that these smaller development teams seem to struggle the most with. Mainly the AI's pathing issues. They constantly hang up and get "confused". In the end I could spend the same amount of time on minecraft survival solo and build more then 20 bricktons could accomplish even after hours of fine tuning how to work around the many bugs castle story has. The grand goal of this game seems to be able to mass an army of AI builders to construct an elaborate fort to defend against the corrupted but in the end if you could seize control of just one of the bricktons and manually control them you would do much much better to achieving this goal. At that point I have to say just stick with minecraft. Until you see a tidal wave of reviews saying they have finally made the AS (artificial stupidity) actually resemble AI
date: then steer clear of this struggling under developed game. Good idea but an extreme failure to polish into a playable game."
